name: Goodbye Mr. Chips
description: This is a simple track game based on the novel. The object is to move through the boarding school to get to the assembly hall and graduation. On your turn, you roll the die and advance the number of squares indicated. When you reach the "Mr. Chips" space, you spin the "Mr. Chips" spinner sending you to a random board location. If you land on a Pompeii space you take an extra turn. The first player to get to the assembly hall, graduates and wins the game.

name: Tee It Up
description:
Tee it up- the funtastic game of golf for 2-6 players is a roll and move game that consists of 3 dice (blue driving dice, green fairway dice, & yellow putting dice), tee markers, bonus trap pass cards, sand trap cards, a pad of score sheets, pencil, wooden trophy and game board. The object of the game is to roll and move along the gameboard adding up strokes for each hole along the way and end the game by being the golfer with the lowest number of strokes. Winner takes the trophy. Scoring is determined by "tee-offs", "fairway shots", "putting shots", and "obstacles".

NOTE: This game also features a "Sudden Death" playoff to break any ties. "Sudden Death" playoff is agreed upon between golfers (players) and then three consecutive holes on the gameboard could be selected for this purpose. Lowest number of strokes wins.

name: I'm a Millionaire
description:
A great economical card game from the turn of the century. The instruction sheet reads "The best game since PIT" on the front.

Cards are passed between players as players try to collect complete circles of related society members. Cards have comical names of people within a society, they could call them cliques rather than circles. (examples: Mrs. Get-there, from Butte, Mr. Clymer from Denver and Major But-in (the character who disturbs the social gatherings)) Each circle has a monetary value associated which is paid to the player who collects the entire circle and turns it in to the bank. The player with the most counters (Counters represent $50,000 each) at the end wins the game.

The rules are very specific and proper etiquette is enforced!!

Typical of the time, early games were designed with religious backgrounds encouraging high sense of morals and etiquette.

name: Eva & Adam
description: This game of "life, buddies and love" very loosely ties into a Swedish comic of the same name aimed at pre-teens. Before playing, all players write down their answers to some "embarrassing question" and these are placed in an envelope. During play, the roll of a die and movement of a communal piece determines what happens in a round. Activities include charades (get points for making the other players guess which persona you're acting out a particular scene as), trivia (everyone can get a point for answering a true-or-false question), a personal question (you get a point just for giving an answer), nothing (because there's nothing like losing your turn), and arbitrary events such as gaining points or losing your next turn (because there's nothing like effectively losing two turns). Once someone has 19 points they win and get to look at the answers in the envelope before anyone else.

name: Pop Stars
description: You are the manager of one or more pop-bands. As a manager it is your job to sell as many records as possible of the band/s you manage. You also has to arrange concerts to get money from ticket-sales and to get more profits from the record sales. To be able to sell records you must also manufacture the lp:s themselves (you can´t sell lp:s you don't have). There is also a billboard kind of chart that will generate money if you can reach the top 3. The game is played over 8 turns, in which you can swap bands during turn 4. In turn 8 the whole game ends with a song contest among all bands in play. The winner is the player that has the most amount of money at the end of the game.

name: Operation Desert Storm
description: Desert Storm is a wargame on the Coalition vs. Iraq war published by Bandai. This game has four scenarios covering the whole war from start to finish. Medium Complexity.

name: D-Weapon: The Game of Space Combat in Dragonar
description:
This is another Japanese wargame set in the world of Dragonar. It is a companion to Metal Armor: The Game of Space Dogfight in Dragonar. Published by Tsukuda Hobbies.

Game # HG-064?@

name: Space Runaway IDEON
description: Ideon is a Tsukuda Hobby science Fiction wargame set in the anime world of Ideon. Basically a Mecha game vs. an alien civilization.

name: BLT: Baby, Lettuce, and Tomato
description:
BLT - Baby, Lettuce, and Tomato: The official Kobolds Ate My Baby! collectible board game!!!

In BLT: Baby, Lettuce, and Tomato players are competing Kobolds, running around the board trying to get all the parts of their favorite sandwich, and get back home to cook them. Depending on the routes they take, they could end up facing all sorts of hazards, like other monsters, or having ingredients stolen from them by other players. Although they claim that this is a collectible board game, I never saw any boards but the original.
mechanics: Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Gissa mitt ord!
description: Players create words with cards, and then the other players try to guess what it is. Whoever is last man standing wins.

name: Nalle och hans vänner
description: Nalle is using different tools but which tools does he already have? Nalle och hans vänner is a quick game where the goal is to be the first to say which tool Nalle already has.

name: Diadochoi: A Divided Uncompleted Empire
description:
The game covers the ceaseless in-fighting amongst Alexander the Great’s Generals after his death. The map stretches from Northern Macedonia and Benghazi in the west to the Caspian Sea in the east. The map uses a more naturalized look than most other AT games and is completely in Japanese, other than the title. Units are of indeterminate size, but include Elephants, ships, and leaders as well as infantry. Also, the counters use mostly Japanese characters, except for the Arabic numerals.
Movement in the game looks to be controlled by leaders, with interception being available to the non-phasing player. Combat units are counted by points and the CRT is percentage-based for losses. The game runs 16 years (315-300 BC) with an impulse track or turn track (?) based on the seasons (9 boxes per year).



First Ad-technos edition
SGB-2 Diadochoi--A divided uncompleted Empire (1983) (JPY 1500)
The first 23 pages cover the history leading up to and concerning the game, including chapters on the generals, tactics of the time, and maps of the battle lines. The following 16 pages are the rules of the game, with a further 8 pages of charts, tables and (mostly) tracks.


Second edition
Issue game of Game Journal #54

name: Napoleon's Russian Campaign "Borodino & Smolensk."
description:
SGB-7 Napoleon’s Russian Campaign (1985) (JPY 6800)
Subtitled “Borodino & Smolensk.”
NRC includes one mapsheet (back printed), 504 counters, one 24-pg rulebook and two (one 32-pg and one 44-pg) historical booklets. Turns are hourly and there is no indication of hex size. Combat units are brigades and divisions with separate leaders. Leaders have four numbers on them (?) while combat units only three (combat, morale and movement). The CRT is by strength point losses and there is a demoralization track as well for each side. The map terrain and its effect chart look very similar to SPI’s old NAW system, with a little more chrome. There are additional rules for fortifications and bridges also.

name: Decline of the Empire 1814-1815
description:
SGB-13 Decline of the Empire 1814-1815 (1986) (JPY 6800)

DotE contains one map, stretching from Dunkerque and Paris on the west edge to Roermoon and Luxemburg City on the east edge. There are 756 counters, along with 8 PAC, many of them off-map strength tracks. There is a 28 pg rulebook and a 24 pg Historical Notes booklet.

This is nothing more than a modified version of Kevin Zucker’s “Campaigns of Napoleon” system, period. The differences I can see are not using individual combat units with historical IDs, instead the designer chose to use icon units (such as artillery or infantry) combined with strength point markers to go underneath. Also, leaders are not on the map and forces are represented by numbered force markers instead. There is an AP Table, but no Attrition Table. The CRT is vastly different, with the addition of negative numbered results and ‘D’ and ‘DD’ results (would sure like to see those!). There is also the ubiquitous Paris Morale Track.

name: Say "Cheese!" The EWOK Picture-Puzzle Card Game
description:
In 1984, Parker Brothers released 3 card games in the Star Wars "Ewok Card Game Assortment" series: Favorite Five, Say "Cheese!", and Paw Pals.

Players are dealt cards that together make a picture. On a player's turn, the top card of the player's stack is drawn and placed next to a previously played card or added to discard stack. If the latter, it's the next players turn. Object is to not play the last piece of the puzzle.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Puzzle

name: Grizzly Adams Save the Animals Adventure Game
description: Help! There's danger in the forest. An unknown hunter has been setting traps and all the animals are caught. They need Grizzly Adam's help. You play Grizzly Adams or one of his friends: Mad Jack, Nakoma or the Indian woman. Try to rescue as many animals as you can and bring them to their dens. But watch out! If you get caught by a trap yourself, you'll have to get Ben or one of the other animals to rescue you.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Area Movement, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Sparkles
description:
Sparkles is a dice rolling game that uses different colored ten-sided dice to play 12 different games. Detailed rules are given for each game, but the basics is that players take turns rolling their dice and logging their scores or results on the score pad.

There are a couple games specifically for very young children, but most are geared toward teens and adults.

Some of the games utilizes numbers and colors, but some get complex and challenging.

name: Hot Dice
description: The object of Hot Dice is to score the highest amount of points possible. After one player has reached 20,000 points in the play, the other players have one last turn in the Scorcher to win.

name: Swap
description: Swap is an exciting game combining a perfect balance of luck and skill. Memory and good judgment aid players to swap smart and accumulate the greatest total value in expensive articles, for the least amount of money. A risk is involved in every deal, since only one half of the items are genuine and the other half are fake and worthless.

name: Brother Bear
description: Basic roll an move childrens game where the players get to be the Bear from the Disney film. During the journey across the board the players will land on event spaces where you experience things related to the film

name: Katz und Maus
description: Try to get as much cheese as possible with your mice. But watch out - the cat is waiting for you.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Dice

name: Lost and Found!
description:
In this children's track game, players try to return three lost items to various Sesame Street locations. Each player receives three cards depicting a lost item and the (3-D cardboard) building where it should be returned. On your turn, you spin the spinner and advance to the space with the character face that the spinner arrow is pointing to. If you land on the Double Spaces in front of a return location, you place the lost item card in your hand on the discard pile. If you have discarded your three cards, and are the first player to land on a Finish space in front of 123 sesame Street, you win.

The game has also been produced in a "The Simpsons" version.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Lalelu
description:
A guessing, singing and dice game for the young.

Contents:
2 sheep
1 moon
1 star
1 large die (1 or 2 pips)
1 game board
1 set of rules

The game board is set up in the box so that it forms a two sided 'ramp' that the sheep set out to climb (ask not why).

There are two 'games' in this box. The first game is a perfunctory singing activity.

The second game involves a race to the top of the game board. One player secretly selects the moon or the star and inserts the chosen piece into their side of the board (hidden from the other player's view). The other player guesses which piece has been inserted. If correct, the guessing player rolls the die and advances their sheep 1 or 2 rungs up the game board. The guessing player now becomes the choosing player, and play alternates in this manner until one sheep makes it to the apex of the board.

Ages 2½ and up.

name: Egypt
description:
Roll a dice and place pieces on the gameboard.
Player with most points wins.

name: Richtfunk
description: The player who is the last one to be able to place a pawn on the board wins.

name: King
description:
King is a game similar to Chess and Checkers.

Originally published in spielbox magazine.

name: Durchmarsch
description:
Each player tries to finish the race first. Each player has cards. A special thing is that each player can also move the opponents pawns.
Graphics: Franz Vohwinkel

name: Joss
description: Players move their pieces on the board and try to occupy the most valuable spaces.

name: Auf nach Oklahoma
description:
Try to get a large piece of Land in Oklahoma.
Spielbox edition no. 39.

name: Chex
description: Chex is a chess variant. However, the board has hexes instead of squares. Like in chess, the goal is to beat the opponent's king.

name: Who on Earth?
description:
Who on Earth? is a party game wherein, in each round, players are each secretly assigned one 'partner' (person to describe) and, after all players answer 3 questions of the form "If your partner was a (garden tool), what would they be?", all players attempt to guess which players were describing which players.

Players score points for correct guessing of who was describing who, and then in a bonus round, the round's lowest scorer turns over a card from a second set of cards with questions of the form "If you use the category of (species of animal) which player would best be described by (sloth)?". All players answer secretly what they believe the card-flipper's answer would be, and for each match, both the matching player and the card-flipping low-scorer earns bonus points.

Essentially a non-competitive party game, as all the players must play completely honestly for the game to work.

name: Arion
description:
Multi-players wargame based on Japanese comics and animation "Arion".
The game represent conflict between Gods of Olympus and son of a God, Arion.

The game map is covering ancient greek.
Each counter is represent a character or a military units.

Players control a God or hero (called character) in story.
Player order vary by random order card per turn. Each turn, players manage movement, combat and miscellaneous actions for fellow characters.

The game include six scenarios for one to ten players.
Winner is determined various victory condition per scenario and character. Especially, the five player game use random victory condition card and it can change during in the game. For example, eliminate certain person, capture certain person or couquer certain area, etc.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Fantasy, Negotiation, Wargame

name: Candy Counter
description: Grab as many candy coated number cards as you can match from your hand. Or add up the candy numbers on the table and buy the treats using a combination of your cards and your Candy Counter coins.

name: Babes in Toyland
description: This game was inspired by the Disney musical, Babes in Toyland. Players move around the board collecting jigsaw pieces of toy soldiers. The first player to complete his or her own toy soldier from these pieces is the winner.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Puzzle

name: Bauboom in Babylon
description:
Build the City of Babylon. When the game is over every building with the same roof color is removed. For those who are left you will earn points.
Spielbox edition No.31

name: Quadrato
description:
36 counters are placed on the 36 spaces of the board. There are positive ones and negative ones. Try to get the positive ones and avoid the negative ones.
Graphics: I. Vohwinkel

name: Sechs: Ex
description: Goal is to earn the most points. Points are counted for areas contolled. Roll 2 dice. Use them to determine on which space on the gameboard you are allowed to place a piece.

name: Insider
description:
One of Gerhard Kodys' better games, the game concerns moving in the right social circles and this gaining the best seats at a restaurant.

From the game rules description:

The Game of Appearance and Reality

The “400”, the “glitterati”, the “beautiful people” and the “VIP’s”. Who wouldn’t want to be part of their world of luxury, glamour and glitz…

However, we can’t all belong to it. The road to the top leads through the best tables at the INSIDER! The super-luxury-IN-temple in the center of the city. “The” restaurant.

Those seen there may rightfully count themselves among “High Society”. But in order to reach your goal must you keep your adversaries at bay. By use of "Scandals", "Rumors", "Contacts" and many other actions you are trying to climb the social ladder while trying to put a spike in the wheel of your opponents. Lucky for you that having a "Bodyguard" handy just might save you from just about everything.

And don't despair. Those who are IN today may be "Total OUT" tomorrow!

name: Cockatoo Contest
description:
Parrot fun that demands memory and dexterity.

Four parrots want to land safely on the ever-higher-growing palm trees. The players pay close attention to which parrot sits where. Because whoever remembers the varying colors well collects the tastiest fruits. Exciting gaming fun that requires a good memory and good dexterity.

name: Sprich genau, hör genau
description:
Practice language in a game - an organization game.

This game develops your child's language skills. It is perfect to prepare a child, through play, for reading and writing. Included are speech and language games with rhyming words and similar-sounding words. Only he who listens carefully and speaks clearly will find the right word. Three game versions provide age-appropriate play possibilities and individual learning fun.

name: Penguin Pat's Fishy Business
description:
Penguin Pat waddles around his track to in front of the next player and randomly announces your action - take a fish, take 2 fish, steal a fish or return a fish.

When you match all 4 fish tails to your board, you win.

name: Step On It
description:
From the publisher:

What a kick! Can you step on the footprint and act out the picture? This game combines the challenge of charades with the development of memory and word-association skills. Here’s how you play: pick a picture card, put it under a giant footprint and—you guessed it!—step on it. Then act out the picture and get the other players to guess what you are. Then go again. As the path grows, you’ll be hopping from footprint to footprint and acting out all kinds of things. It’s so much fun, Mom and Dad might want to play, too! Comes with 50 picture cards, 20 colorful vinyl footprints and easy-to-follow instructions for beginners and more advanced little players.

name: GiOstraKon
description:
A PDF print-and-play game set in the world of Ostrakon.
In this new daVinci game you play the role of a philosopher trying to reach the Merry-go-round of Wisdom.
To move, the other players must give you their vote!

The game materials are:
- a board
- a white/black arrow board
- 12 philosophers
- 12 ostrakons
- 12 tokens
- 12 team cards
- rules (in Italian)

you can download the game from www.arima.it
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Railroad Big Party
description:
Aoste-Gare-de-l’Est, December 31

While waking up (at about 8pm), Lulu and Dédé decide to go to the party in the village hall of Saint-Andre-le-Gaz. They intend to get there before Nono and Kiki, who also go out only at 8pm because they were playing Playstation all the afternoon…

The 4 characters go through the countryside, at feet or by train, trying to get to the village hall but on the way long, they may meet pals. Those never fail to invite our guys to drink a glass of beer, or to smoke weed. They never refuse an invitation (they’re no beasts).

Nevertheless, each one will be careful not to arrive too drunk at the festival in order to have a chance of getting chicks… It would also be better to bring flowers but as all the florists are closed down at this time, it will be necessary to find some on the road.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Space Race Card Game
description:
Space Race is a simple card game designed for two players, though more can play with additional card sets (as there is no player interaction whatsoever).

The object of the game is to complete a round trip through the Solar System by drawing ten planet cards in their proper order. (The order will be unfamiliar, though, as it goes Earth -> Saturn -> Jupiter -> Mars -> Uranus -> Neptune -> Venus -> Mercury -> Earth). Each card features well executed art done in a style similar to golden age science fiction pulp magazines.

The game consists of two identical decks with cards numbered 1-10. These cards represent round trips the the Solar System, starting with "Take Off" (Card 1) and ending with "Landing On Earth" (Card 10). Players take a deck and shuffle it, then place it before them. The first player draws a card. If it is "Take Off" (Card 1), they place it in front of them and draw the next card. If the next card is a planet but not Card 2, they discard it in a discard pile next to their original pile and draw again, until they draw a card that says "Next player goes". The next player takes a turn, and draws until they get a "Next player goes" card. Chance cards such as "lost on the moon," "Sputnik," and "Danger--Comets" can affect a player's turn.

Players may draw from either pile, so there is a memory element, as you must remember which pile your next planetary target was in.

All cards must be discarded in the pile next to the pile from which they were drawn.

The goal is to collect all 10 cards, in sequence.

Rules list a variant for three or more players through using multiple copies of the game.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Heiter bis Wolkig
description: Move your pawns over clouds to win a race.

name: Measles
description:
"Measles, the ultimate stacking games, combines the elements of balance, coordination and luck with strategy of attempting to outscore an opponent, or gain a scoring advantage of at least five points.

Game components include 1 base tile and 29 wooden playing tiles. Each playing tile has a pattern of red spots (measles) on its surface. Every measle is scored as one "spotpoint" following completion of a round of play.

Each of the 29 playing pieces also has 3 randomly drilled holes in it. This gives every playing tile a unique weight and balance."
...from the rules

name: Passt Genau
description:
A "look-carefully" game about abstract and spatial thinking.

The cars are parked hither and yon all across the parking lot - but illegally-parked vehicles get towed immediately! But which cards are parked incorrectly? The players need a keen eye to help out Petra the meter maid.

name: Mickey Mouse Club Game
description: This is a "Cootie" type game in which players try to assemble one of the Mickey Mouse Club characters. On your turn you spin a spinner to see what body parts you may add. The characters MUST be assembled in an upright position, so the legs must be added first, then the body, and lastly the arms and head. The first player to complete a character wins.

name: Casdon Football
description: Hands on soccer much like the "bubble" hockey games of today where two players face off in a match of dexterity and control while moving the soccer ball down the field.

name: Roll-A-Goal
description: A soccer game where you decide every turn to move, pass or shoot on a large checkerboard pitch. You take your team of 9 players and move them around the board in order to defend your goal or to take the ball to your opponents goal and score.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Räuberjagd
description: One player is a thief the other one a police officer. The thief tries to get out of the city without getting caught.

name: Sesame Street Number Puzzles Game
description: This is a children's puzzle building game with a Sesame Street theme. Each piece in a puzzle has a number on it. To begin, you must spin a "1" or "Wild" on the spinner. You then take the #1 piece of a puzzle and place it in front of you. After that, you may collect pieces in any order, assembling them as you collect them. Each area on the spinner has two numbers. You may collect either numbered piece indicated (but not both). Spinning the Wild space let's you collect any piece. The first player to complete his or her puzzle wins. An advanced game requires players to build 2 puzzles.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Puzzle

name: Hang Glider
description:
This is a Japanese hang gliding game and your goal in the game is to reach your objectives on the map without crashing.

Published by Ad Technos for their Sports and Adventure series.

name: Ark
description:
The object of the game is to earn more points than any other players by building an ark, loading the ark with 8 pairs of animals, plus Noah and Mrs. Noah and by doing good deeds.

Players start each turn with six cards and must play as many cards as possible. The player has a "corral" where he can hold up to four singles or pairs (including Mr. and Mrs. Noah). When all three parts of the ark are complete, up to eight pairs may be moved on the ark, plus Mr. and Mrs. Noah. When one player has a full ark, the game ends.

Players can play not only to their own ark or corral, but also to other players' arks and corrals. Completing a part of another player's ark, giving another player a pair for his corral or ark, or completing a pair in a player's corral is considered a "good deed". For each one the player collects a "good deed" card good for points at the end of the game. Good deed cards can also be used to cancel "misfortune" cards drawn from the deck.

name: Drive to the Danube, 1945
description:
A DTP wargame on the German Operation Spring Awakening, Hungary, March 1945.

This is a forerunner of SS Abyss.

name: Action Baseball
description:
From the Game Box -

With Action Baseball, you are the manager, coordinating your team's action against your opponent - batting, strategic plays, pitching, defense, and counter-strategies! Your decisions direct the game flow, play-by-play, inning-by-inning.

Action Baseball is an original, two-person interactive card game with play dynamics true to the integrity and spirit of baseball. No random dice. No restrictive charts. Instead, you determine the action!

Enjoy the rich tradition and excitement of baseball anytime, anywhere with Action Baseball!

Action Baseball contains:
two play decks
rule book
fold-out playing field
6 runner discs
score pads

name: Operation Dovecote
description: The game comes with two 11x17" map, 280 counters, rules. The map scale is about 1.5 miles per hex. Each combat unit is one platoon to battalion. Turns are 8 hrs. The game simulates the opening few days of the dramatic Egyptian assault across the Suez Canal in October, 1973. The game includes an air game system, a ground system and unique rules where command and control are critical for movement purposes. Use of SAM missiles and SAGGER AT play important roles to keep the Israeli at bay. At first, it appears as a "David vs Goliath" battle because of the disparity of forces. The Egyptian needs to create breaches and bridging and move quickly before the balance favors the Israeli. Time is not a friend to either side at various times in the game.

name: Grease
description: Compete at placing bids on various records, with each player each using a deck of pre-set bids. The player with the records having the greatest point value at the end is the winner.

name: Party for Pooh!
description:
This picture matching game, with a Winnie the Pooh theme, is actually two games-in-one...
Pooh's Birthday Party: In this game players try to gather up Pooh's friends for the party. On your turn you spin the spinner, place your finger on the same color Dialer hole indicated, and turn the Dial until your finger falls through the hole by Kanga & Roo. If the pointer points to Piglet, Eeyore, Tigger or Kanga and Roo, you may collect the piece of your chosen color that matches that character (if you haven't already). If it points to Pooh, you may collect the Pooh pawn. Be the first to collect the Pooh Pawn and four character pieces of your color to win. The winner gets to assemble all the character pieces to form the gameboard for Game 2.
The Path to Tigger's House: In this game players once again spin the spinner and rotate the color dial, but this time they look at the gift that the character is holding. They then move the Pooh pawn along the gameboard path to the next space with the matching gift picture. The winner is the player that moves the pawn to the last honey pot space by Tigger's house.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Gung Ho
description: The game of Gung Ho is played on an 11 x 11 grid of points. The playing pieces are plastic "towers" that are inserted into the grid points. The idea of the game is to line up a fixed number of towers into a row either diagonally/vertically/or horizontally (5 for 2 players, or 4 for 3-4 players). The game is quite simple, players take turns placing a tower piece into a game board location (once placed it cannot be moved). The first player to meet the victory condition is the winner.

name: Penny Candy
description: This is a simple matching game with a candy store theme. To begin, the 36 candy cards (gumdrops, candy corn, lollipops etc.) are randomly inserted into slots on the board. On your turn you spin the spinner and get either a result of "1 cent" or "2 cents". If you spin a 1, you pull 1 card from a slot. If you don't have a card in front of you, place it face up in front of you. If you do have a candy card in front of you, but this card doesn't match it, put it back (and remember what it is for later). If you do have a candy card in front of you and this card matches it, set both cards aside and draw again. A spin of 2 allows you to draw 2 cards on your turn. The player with the most matches when all the candy cards have been drawn from the board wins.

name: Crusher Joe: Roleplay Game in CrusherJoe
description: This is another Crusher Joe game from Tsukuda hobbies but this time uses a magic realm type system.

name: Scaventure Kids
description:
Scaventure Kids asks kids Ages 6 - 12 to locate items around the house or yard or even create, perform or draw new things themselves. Whether it's demonstrating a pet trick, making a sandwich a gorilla would like or learning to hula dance.

Editorial Review from Amazon.com:
"A scavenger hunt in a can, Scaventure Kids provides everything needed to plan and execute a challenging hunt. Included in the cardboard container are 150 cards, instructions, and team stickers. The cards each have four items for a team to find or do. Cards ask players to do things like "Find two bags with different store names" or "Have your team act out a scene from your favorite movie." Each team takes out cards and has 30 minutes to carry out the tasks. At the rendezvous, the teams share their finds and winners are chosen. For rainy days, vacations, or parties, Scaventure Kids is a simple and creative activity that fosters teamwork and creative problem-solving. --Lee Strucker"

name: Quick Draw McGraw Card Game
description: Quick Draw McGraw was manufactured by Edu-Cards Manufacturing Corporation, New York City. There are 36 cards in the deck, each 9cm long x 5.8cm wide. Cards are numbered one through ten in the upper right and lower left corners. Each card has circular symbols in the center representing one of four "suits" and matching the number printed in the corners. The circular symbols are supposedly "bullet holes" - the result of McGraw's ability. The "Ace" or number one card features a sketch of "Quick Draw McGraw", with the words Lucky One printed across the top and bottom of the card.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Trade Wars
description: Score as many points as possible by getting the cards that complete any list or lists found on the cards.

name: Quick Draw McGraw Private Eye Game
description:
"QUICK DRAW is trying to solve some of the mysteries that he has heard about. He needs the help of the players in this game to find the missing parts to each mystery. Each player will use one of QUICK DRAW'S friends, BLABBER, SNOOPER, BABA LOOEY, or DOGGIE DADDY to help him."

Players take turns spinning the spinner and moving around the board. The space they land on determines which pile they draw a card from. Players may challenge other players for cards, and even steal cards from other players' hands. The first player to collect all eight puzzle cards detailing their assigned mystery wins.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Puzzle
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Star Hop: Game of the Cosmos
description:
Ages 10 and up

Components: Game Board (Milky Way Galaxy + more), Instructions, Star Hop Decoder, Star Hop Navigator's Manual, 4 Rocket Playing Pieces, Mission Cards, Hop Cards, and GNC Cards.

Object: The object of Star Hop is to be the first player to acquire 25 Galactic Navigation Credits (GNC's). Players are awarded GNC's when they successfully complete missions described on the Star Hop Mission Cards.

Description: Players become space travelers and visit the solar system, comets, black holes, super-giants, quasars, and other galaxies. It's a fun and competitive way to learn of the discoveries of modern astronomy.
publishers: Carolina Biological Supply Company, Teaching Concepts

name: Derby Dog Race Game
description:
Components:

Folding Game Board, Blue Cards, 6 Greyhound figures

Description:

This is a very old dog-racing wagering game published by "The Cardora". All game play was determined by a set of cards, which dictated odds, events, and race results. The ceramic greyhound figures look good if in good condition.

name: Starmada: The Sovereign Stars
description:
Combining the epic scope of Twilight Imperium with the excitement and adaptability of Starmada, The Sovereign Stars contains three major components:


First, the races of Twilight Imperium are fully defined within the Starmada rules system, including starship designs, weapons, and equipment.
Second, it adapts the races outlined in the Starmada rulebook to Twilight Imperium, giving players the opportunity to decide the future of the Terran Empire, the Arcturan Federation, and the major players in the Starmada universe.
Finally, The Sovereign Stars contains guidelines for linking tactical battles in Starmada with the strategic level of Twilight Imperium, letting players control the destiny of their empires at multiple levels of play.


Expands:

Starmada X
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Political, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Magnetic Poetry The Game
description: What is "poetry" really all about? We say wordplay-mixing up words and experimenting with different ways of putting them together. You'll play with words in a silly, fast and furious competition that really gets your creative juices flowing. Object: To score the most points after five rounds of play by composing poems in two minutes once you get a topic.

name: Barbie Fun Fashions Memory Game
description: A memory game featuring Barbie Game fashions. Put on a fabulous fashion show with your favorite Barbie fashions. An easy-to-learn memory game that's fun to play. The object of the game is to be the first to match-up and complete their Barbie fashion cards by remembering where they are - no reading required.

name: Der kleine Schlaumeier
description: The goal is to advance your figure to the end of a 10 space track first. The board has a spinner in the middle with 22 yellow spaces showing a letter and a number, 4 red spaces showing a sad or angry face and a number and 2 green spaces showing a happy face. On a players turn he spins the spinner. If it stops on a letter he takes a card and reads out the category on it (eg "profession" or "funny birthday present"). The neighbor to his right has to say a word that starts with the given letter and fits the category in 10 seconds, if he does so he may advance 1 space on his track. The other players still have the chance to advance 1 space by rolling the number on the letter space of the spinner. If the spinner stops on a red space all players have to roll the die and go back 1 space if they roll the number on the spinner's space. If the spinner stops on a green space the player who spun may advance 2 spaces.

name: Legepladsen
description: Legepladsen is a game for children. Each child has a Lego-figure which has to collect 3 pieces of Lego each. The game can be played in 3 different ways depending on the age of the child. There are 3 different piles of cards, depending on which variation you choose. With the youngest children you simply have to draw a card and then move the same number as shown on the card. With older children you can choose either to play with addition or subtraction. To move on the board you have to draw 2 cards and move the sum of the cards. When you pass the symbol with the piece of Lego you can take one. The winner is the first player to collect 3 pieces of Lego and then get back to start. There are 2 tiles which can be placed on the board: Either you can have an extra turn or you miss your turn. Playing the game children can learn to count and calculate as well as game-mechanics as turn-taking, drawing cards, taking extra turns and missing a turn.

name: The Game is Nirtz
description:
This abstract game consists of a plastic game board (9x9 matrix), ten red and ten yellow tokens (numbered 1-5; two tokens of each number), and a plastic storage tray.

At the onset of the game, players arrange their tokens in two straight rows at opposite ends of the board. The objective of the game is to move the tokens to form a straight unbroken line of 7 tokens across the board, extending at a right angle to the original arrangement. Players take turns, each moving one token at a time. Tokens are moved the number of spaces indicated (i.e., token five must move five spaces).

The game includes two variations.

name: The Great Ontario Trivia Challenge
description:
This game is a roll-and-move trivia game, using questions based on the history and culture of the province of Ontario, Canada. The board depicts two concentric game tracks around the edges , and the center has a stylized map of the province. The questions are divided into five categories: Sports; History; Industry; People; Places.

Contents:
Gameboard
Ontario Trivia Question Book 8 Game Pawns
32 Loon Coins
1 Die
1 Bookmark
8 player tokens

name: Mythfire
description:
"Jason! I know you're there!" Hector's voice echoed across the valley. "You can hide behind your goblins and skeletons, but I know you're there, and I am coming for you!" He knew Jason could hear him, and he knew that his arch-enemy could not resist such a challenge. But how would he respond?

The answer wasn't long in coming. A huge boulder sailed across the valley and smashed into the ground just short of Hector's forces. One of his men went down screaming, hit by a sliver of rock. So Jason had a cyclops in his army, did he? Hector looked over to his minotaurs, roaring and waving their battleaxes. They would make short work of a cyclops, and then his ogres would begin the slaughter. He gave the hand signals for his line of mighty beasts to advance. This would be a day to remember!

If he had noticed the shadow that flitted over him, he might have looked up and seen Jason's roc beginning its dive on his forces...

Mythfire is a 2-player wargame of mythical beasts, mostly from Greek mythology. Players choose their armies from an array of creatures with varying abilities, then fight to the death.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board

name: Baseball's Greatest Moments
description: Baseball's Greatest Moments is a game in which each player's knowledge of baseball trivia is put to the test. Two to six players buy "souvenirs" and "baseball memorabilia" with the answer points awarded for correct answers. The winner must acquire 1500 points in souvenirs/memorabilia, 100 points in answer points, and answer a final challenge question in the last zone of the game board.

name: Hat In The Ring
description:
"Hat in the Ring" is a throwback to an era when political party conventions still were perceived to hold an important role in the nomination of each party's candidates.

In this game, three to eight players compete for their party's nomination; however, in a classroom setting, additional roles such as Campaign Manager, Treasurer, etc. may be assigned to other participants. Players go through a series of primaries, then try to gain the required number of delegates at their party's convention to win on a given ballot. Delegates are won in blocks of 10; a player must therefore claim at least 660 out of the 1,300 delegates to win a given ballot and claim the nomination.

name: Auction
description:
Players attempt to “furnish a home” as quickly as possible by acquiring furniture cards at “auction” or at “shop prices.” They must also sell furniture by auction.

“Rent” has to be paid players acquire the required kitchen and bedroom furniture cards. Furnishing a second bedroom produces rental income from a “lodger”.

The winner is the first player to have acquired a full set of furniture cards plus one other item.

name: 撃墜王
description:
This is an Japanese air combat game set in the Pacific during World War 2.

Note: Gekitsui(撃墜) Ō(王) means "Flying Ace" (word to word: "Shooting down aircraft expert").

name: View-Master Grand Prix
description:
The game is played on a 4’ x 3’ board depicting a race track. The track has grid spaces on it and players roll dice to move (one space for each number).

If a car lands on a space with a picture on it, the player has to pick up the Viewmaster viewer and place a reel in it. They then roll a die and advance the reel by the number shown. Peering in the viewer, they will see a 3D scene that will either give them an advantage or a handicap.

The game came with four Matchbox cars; these are now very rare collectibles.

name: Hydra!: The Ultimate Starcruiser?
description:
Hydra! (subtitled "The Ultimate Starcruiser?") was one of Grenadier's small-box Midi Games - a series that was also referred to as The Great Little Games Line. This was a line of four games that were somewhat larger than a typical boxed microgame of the day.

Hydra! could reasonably be described as "Ogre in Space." As in Ogre, one player has a single huge unit while the other has many small units. Here the large unit is the eponymous Hydra, which has phasers, proton torpedoes, energy sapper discs, a gyro-de-stabilizer, a molecular structure distorter, and a force field projector. The other player controls an alien space fleet consisting of frigates, battle cruisers, larger battle cruisers, and mine sweepers. Damage for both sides is marked off on record sheets.

The Hydra player's goal is simply to destroy as many enemy ships as possible, but players are invited to make up other scenarios and some extra counters are provided to facilitate this.

Hydra is identified on the side of the box as product number 7001. However, on its rear cover-sheet the game is identified as product number 7002. This probably explains why some examples of Hydra have been found bearing the rear cover-sheet for the Midi Game "Journey", as that sheet was erroneously marked as product number 7001, which corresponded to the numbering on the side of the Hydra box.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation

name: The Sweeney
description:
It has a yellow and black duo-toned drawing of Regan and Carter on the box, and claims to be 'an exciting game for four players'.

The game parts are: a board, a scoreboard, 16 small cards and 4 small plastic figures representing The Villains (typical Burgler Bill 'swag' type figures) and The Sweeney (Policeman blowing a whistle). Oh, and two dice.

The idea is that you work in pairs, two players are the villains, and two are The Sweeney. You have to meet up with your partner at randomly designated places on the board for a raid. When you successfully raid a location you get points to add to the scoreboard, and the winner is the first up the scoreboard to number 14.

name: Bug Bingo
description: A humorous bug themed variant of Bingo, where players roll two dice and cover any of the pictures on their cards that match the images shown on both dice. Certain die rolls force pictures to be uncovered. Get all four corners covered, or four-in-a-row in any direction, and you win.

name: EasyStar
description:
Game Scenario: there are two space empires that don't like each other, and their starships fight whenever they meet. Okay, so it's not very profound; whaddya want from a free game?

EasyStar is a 2-to-4-player tactical starship combat game that allows you great flexibility in designing your spaceships, without having to print out or erase worksheets for your ships every time you play. It does this with a system of track charts and counters. All you need to provide is one or two six-sided dice. The emphasis is on fast play and blowing things up, not on long, drawn-out slug fests. I created this game because I wanted unlimited variety in ship design and tactics, without getting bogged down in range measurements, turning angles, power factors, or checking off gazillions of ship-damage boxes. Game features include:


Reusable track sheets for ship design and keeping score
Up to 18 ships for each player
Five different sizes of starship, from very small to excessively big
Speed and weapons capacity for each ship type can be altered
All weapons can be custom-fitted for range and power
Beams, missiles, torpedoes, and point-defense weapons
Auxiliary devices including ECM, enhanced targeting, and deflector shields
Carriers with two kinds of fighters
Special advantages for each player's flagship
Movement rules including simplified inertia & momentum
Quick combat resolution - usually 1 die roll per weapon
Critical hits
Ramming attacks and accidental collisions
Optional rules for three-player and four-player games and campaign games

name: S.L.O.B.S. III
description:
The Simple Large Outer-space Battle System lets you fight very big space battles. If 42 ships and 12 fighters isn't a big enough battle for you, then print more sheets of counters and double your fleet, or triple it, or quadruple it, even! There is no record-keeping at all; the emphasis is on fast play and interstellar mayhem.

S.L.O.B.S. III is a complete game, with maps and counters. All you provide is two 6-sided dice.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board

name: Samurai Wargame Rules
description: Samurai wargame rules is a lightweight set of rules focusing on 25mm squad-level combat from 1100AD to 1500AD in Japan where a single figure represents a single man with its own unique fighting ability. Samurai wargame rules simulates the skirmishes between the private armies of rival Daimyos. It is an 18 page stapled rulebook.

name: Eiyu Sengoku Jidai
description:
Another multi-player Sengoku Era game, something like a paired down version of Feudal Lords.

Published by Sho Kikaku in 1991.

name: Every Second Counts
description:
"Every Second Counts is a game of "Family fun that gives everyone a chance to shine" for 4 players Ages 10 and up

It was made in 1987 by Peter Pan and is based on the BBC Quiz Show of the same name which was hosted by magician Paul Daniels and which ran from 1986 to 1993 in the UK.

The box describes the game as follows:

"It's not just what you know - it's how quickly you can shout it out. Pit your WITS against the clock!"
categories: Action / Dexterity, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Operation Space Chase
description:
From the Publisher:

It takes mathematical agility to pilot this fleet of space ships! Players use their place value and addition/subtraction skills to try to move all of their ships to the space station first. A great way to make practicing math a "blast".
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Math, Number, Space Exploration
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: KokkoKid
description:
From the Kidult website:

KokkoKid is a very easy game with some surprises in store!

4 hungry fearsome crocodiles go about in a lagoon that separates the stormy river from the lake of tranquility.

The hunting has began, but our crocodiles are not very smart...that's right, they are only able to go straight and imagine this, they do not know how to stop... to do this they must go to the opposite side. Now it is your turn. Will you be able to help your little fish arrive to their destination safely with your die, some cunningness and a touch of luck? The player that will save the most fishes wins.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: KromoSauri
description:
From the Kidult website:

Who knows which colour dinosaurs were? Nobody! So have fun and colour them as you wish! Dear children, dear parents, who is writing these words has designed the animals you see, he is the father of three wonderful daughters Alessia, Alice and Michela who, like all the other children, are always searching for something new to do and to learn from. These unpublished images and these games are inspired at Bookgames a series of books designed to help parents grow with their children in a more simple way, more profitable and fun: PLAYING WITH THEM.

These games aim at those children that, in most cases, can not read yet or they are learning. That is why every character on a coloured pedestal has a big initial and a name completely written with capital letters. Children love to play: that is why every picture to be cut can become a playing card, or it can be folded along the base so that it stands and be played with.

The Kromosauri game includes 54 pictures to cut, one coloured series of (27), one black and white series of (27) (that you can colour yourself) and a series of (27) presentation cards with a brief story where the character presents himself. There are also the rules to 6 different games to able you to use the picture cards you have cut.

Thanks to this material you could have fun with your children getting them involved (and getting yourself involved) by playing with one of the 6 games offered (or you could make up new ones)

name: F*ck This! (Keeping It Clean)
description:
From the publisher: "A 29-card expansion for F*ck This! A set of cards that you can use to substitute into the main game for use with those who have more delicate sensibilities than you. Only 29 cards might not be enough to pull it off, but it's a start."

Expansion #4 of F*ck This!.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Mature / Adult, Word Game

name: Billo
description:
Perfect information, no luck involved abstract strategy game.

A checkers variant on the classic 8*8 square board.

Every player has two kinds of pieces: round ones and square ones. Square pieces have an hole and round pieces fit into the hole, so two pieces of the same color of different shapes can share the same space.

Square pieces capture opponent's round ones.
Round pieces capture opponent's square ones.

Pieces that reach the opposite side of the board become more powerful, as in checkers.

name: Sovereign Seas Lite
description:
Sovereign Seas Lite is a nautical combat war game which simulates the period from 1860-1870. Sovereign Seas Lite is intended for 2 or more players. Complexity is medium. Time to learn is from 30-45 minutes.

Sovereign Seas Lite is the early descendant of Queen Victoria's Navy, a significantly updated and more refined game that covers naval combat from 1860 to 1906.

Players assume the role of either the British or the French in an attempt to meet the victory conditions of several different scenarios.

Sovereign Seas Lite uses EOR (See Designer Notes March 97), so any kind of dice can be used in any combination.

The Addendum #1 for Sovereign Seas Lite is a collection of beta rules and Design Your Own information for the Sovereign Seas Lite game system. The addendum includes instructions for Design Your Own ship designs, the beta V3.0 rules of SSL, and the original ship lists from v1.0 of Sovereign Seas. This addendum is not a complete game and is intended as an unofficial supplement to the Sovereign Seas Lite game system.

name: Acquisition
description:
According to the rules Acquisition was created for The Shidler Group (a commercial real estate investment firm) by Prince Joli Kansil, presumably as an educational tool of some sort. It is not clear if it was ever published as such.

The game is designed for 12 players plus an umpire, but can be played by fewer (the rules only specifically mention changes for as few as 8 players). The umpire is not strictly necessary, but would make sense if the game were intended to be played by groups of children. The game is played cooperatively.

Each player has his or her own board. Each corresponds to a city or section of a city in the US, and is a stylized representation of one of its commercial real estate districts. Players move around their board by die roll (using the difference of two dice, not the sum) and can buy properties when they land on them. When a player rolls doubles they do not move, but all owned properties pay rent to the owner (from the bank).

There are a few other aspects to the system. When players buy or sell property they may do so at face value or may try rolling a 12-sided die to "negotiate." Odds are they will do better this way but there is a chance they will do considerably worse. A player may travel to another player's board, which allows them or the other player to propose a joint venture, where both chip in to buy a property. Only the board's player gets rent, but since it is a cooperative game this is not an issue. Finally, there are spaces which cause players to draw event cards which do the usual sorts of things.

Play is for a specified amount of time - 75 minutes is suggested in the rules. At this point the net worth of all players is totaled, and if more than one group is playing (which would require multiple copies of the game), the one with the most money is the winner.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Ancient Naval Wargames Rules: 500 BC to AD 500
description:
A small rulebook of 36 pages, it simulates naval warfare from 500 BC to AD 500 and thus cover the period from the Greco-Persian wars to the fall of the Roman Empire in the west.

The rules focus on speed of play with beginners to ancient naval wargaming in mind, and is suitable for wargames from a few ships per side to larger fleet actions.

Three appendices are also included, providing a brief guide to ancient naval fleet compositions and tactics as well as some help with the painting of ancient ship models.

name: Sneak-a-Snack
description:
See the mice scurrying across the kitchen floor, hoping to get some cheese to bring back to the mouse hole? Will they be able to sneak the cheese past the sleeping cat, or will the cat awake and chase them down.

How to play:
Players roll the die and move their mouse game piece across the board toward the cheese. Pieces of cheese can be captured one at a time when the mouse lands on the squares adjacent to the cheese board. Mice hurry to return to the mouse hole once they have a piece of cheese. Any cheese safely returned is theirs to keep.

Whenever a player rolls the star symbol on the die the cat awakens.

name: Market
description: This card game is a variant of Parker Brother's famous game of 'Pit', and is played in much the same manner. The instructions state: 'The game of Market or Covent Garden is so called solely because it is founded on the names of fruit or vegetables which are bought or sold, as in a market'. The game's contents are 72 market cards and 72 tally cards, instructions, 1 fresh card, 1 stale card and 1 market prices card. According to the box, the game is: "Humorous - Original - Exciting" and "the latest and best card game for laughter and skill". The game was made by the Kum-Bak Mfg Co Ltd of Leicester Square in London.
publishers: KUM-BAK Sports, Toys, & Games, MFG Co. Ltd

name: Monopoly: I Love Lucy
description:
Relive Lucy's greatest schemes as you wheel and deal in classic Monopoly style. Vie to own 28 of the funniest "I Love Lucy" episodes and ultimately control the "I Love Lucy" enterprise.

Contains special board with large picture of the cast, and pewter playing pieces.
categories: Economic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Negotiation
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Atlanta in a Box
description: A Monopoly clone from Late For The Sky; this version is based in Atlanta, Georgia. It has spaces such as Georgia Tech, The Varsity, Zoo Atlanta, Dekalb Farmers Market, Turner Field, Georgia State Capitol, and Jimmy Carter Boulevard. Cards include local events and staples of life in Atlanta.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Missions? Impossible!
description:
From the KenMGames website:

"Missions? Who ... Us? Impossible!"
As anyone who has ever had to come up with a "winning idea" knows the same thing rarely works twice. The same goes for missions in the church. Yester-year's tea socials and bake sales just don't pack them in like they used to. It's time to get radical. It's time to get whimsical. It's time to go out on a limb and invest yourself in a scheme that's just so absurdly crazy it might even work! Or not ...

Download the game at: http://kenmgames.wordpress.com
categories: Card Game, Humor, Print & Play, Religious

name: The Yacht Race
description: This is a sailing game published in Perth, Australia based on Australia's Americas Cup defense. Two dice are rolled to move the plastic yachts around the course. Each die represents the number of spaces you may move on a given track. If you roll doubles, you may take a card from the locker. The game is very abstract and although the map of the Perth coast is nice, it bears small resemblance to sailing. The rule book has some background notes on the event.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Een 10 voor topo
description:
A game in which you learn the Dutch and European cities. The two-sided boardgame has 3 levels of difficulty and includes bluffing, geography, memory and Euros.

Nominated for 'Speelgoed van het Jaar' 2002 in the Netherlands.

name: Topolino
description:
Topolino...

It is a push your luck children's dice game with a mouse and cheese theme. Players take turn to roll the cheese dice, each with a hidden mice color inside.

If none of the dice fall with the open side facing up, the round is over, and all the cheese dice go to the next player on the left. Play continues clockwise.

If one or more dice fall with the open side facing up, players decide whether they want to stop or continue throwing the dice.

The first player to collect 7 mice of the same color wins.

name: Swoop
description: A beautifully-produced game on the subject of bird watching. The game is roll and move, and has trivia questions, but for most birdwatchers the lovely cards and components make up for this.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Predators & Prey
description:
The theme of this game is summed up in the title. Players are dealt a hand of six cards, each depicting animals. Each animal is labeled as either PREY or PREDATOR and has a numeric value based on its strength in the wild. Players also have a playing piece that's actually a small plastic animal (my set has a zebra, a gorilla, an elephant, and a rhinoceros).

On a player's turn, she may either toss their hand and draw six new cards or play a PREY card face up. Then, going 'round the table to the left, each player may play a PREDATOR card of equal or greater strength. The next player in succession can only play if their PREDATOR card is of higher strength than any previously played predator. Also, any predator played against the prey must also inhabit a common continent with the prey (color coded spheres on the cards--see, educational).

If no PREDATOR cards were played, the owner of the PREY card moves forward the strength of that card. If one or more PREDATOR cards were played, the owner of the highest one played battles the owner of the PREY card via an on-board spinner. A player spins and consults the difference in value between the predator and prey (four possibilities: 0, +1, +2, or higher). Wherever the spinner stops, simply check to see the color of the difference in values. If that number is yellow, the prey escapes, if it's red, the predator "captures" the prey. The owner of the winning animal card moves forward a number of spaces equal to the PREY card's strength.

The spinner is divided into only five segments. Four seem to be of equal size and the larger one (about 40% of the dial) is all yellow. So, the odds are with the prey. But with a more-than-plus-two differential, there's less than a 15% chance of escape.

At the end of a player's PREY turn, she replenishes her hand to six cards.

The movement track is 50 squares long. First animal playing piece to the end is the winner.

This is probably not technically a children's game, but I think that's the audience that it suits best (though the idea of those cute little animals being "captured" by predators might be a bit much for some kids).

name: Scoop!
description:
From the Invisible City Productions website:

A fast-paced game of competitive journalism for two to six players.

Sponsored by Software Consulting Services, providers of newspaper software solutions.

Based on Economy Class by Jeremy P. Bushnell

There's always something happening in Action City! That's why the Action City Times is on the lookout for fresh, hot stories from up-and-coming journalists. You're itching to be the next big name in on-the-scene reporting. So get out there, do your research, and come back to the Action City Times to pitch your story. If the Editor likes it, you're in print. Just look out, because other players may try to scoop your story out from under you. Good luck!

Object: To sell three stories to the Action City Times before any other journalist. Stories happen at Locations, and good research makes for stories that sell.

Download here;
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/97/scoop
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Jovian Syzygy
description:
From the Invisible City website:

A dance with Jovian moons for 1 to 4 players

During the last leg of an astral race to Neptune and back, you and your competitors were caught in a cosmic storm near Jupiter. Banding together you survived the storm, but it sapped almost all of your psychic energy. Now you must harness and store energy created by lunar confluences to build up enough power to return to Earth and win the race.

Object: To accumulate 16 or more Psi by riding on a satellite that begins a line of three or more satellites.

Download here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/94/jovian-syzygy
categories: Abstract Strategy, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Tabletop Quarterback
description:
From the Developers:

"This game was developed to fill a need in the sports game market. Our goal was to develop a realistic football game that could be played anywhere in a relatively short time by almost anybody. Yes there are some very realistic games out there, but they are too complicated for a lot of people to play, such as a father and a son. Other games are simpler, but they leave out the drama and agony of tough calls (go for it or punt?). We feel we have met our goals with Tabletop Quarterback. You can play a game and keep full statistics in less than an hour. Some of the "experts" who developed this game have been trounced by wives and 11 year old kids. We think youl like it and get caught up in the action just like we have."

Overview:
Basic football rules apply; things like 4 tries to make 10 yards, 6 points for a touchdown, 3 points for a field goal. The risks are here: such as the probability of making a long field goal, an unexpected turnover, a drive-killing penalty. Usually, sound football savvy will get you through. But don't be afraid to make some chancey calls as they can work and really turn a game around.

Call play, both players roll dice, compare results to chart. Repeat as indicated by rules. Game is over after 4 quarters.

name: Tac of War
description:
A strategy war game that is fun and challenging. Your mission is to defeat the opponent by capturing its commander with your special forces or infantry.

Web site: www.vsmartgames.com

name: Wacky Water
description: Secretly dial in your opponent(s) and soak them using a Water Card. Drawing a Defense Card should help, but can a Giant Sponge absorb all the water from a Geyser?

name: Täter unter uns: Die Früchte des Herrn Zorn
description: One of the party games with a murder mystery theme that hit the German market in the late eighties and were quite popular at that time.

name: Detroit in a Box
description: A Monopoly clone from Late For The Sky; this version is based in Detroit, Michigan. It has spaces such as Coneys, Kowalski Sausage, Detroit Zoo, Eastern Market, Tiger Stadium, Renaissance Center, and Bell Isle. The tokens include a spark plug, model T, musical note, hot dog, football, and a mitt. Cards include local events and staples of life in Detroit.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Send aben videre! Junior
description:
A player draws a card with a simple question and passes the annoying monkey timer to another player who has to answer the question before the monkey laughs.

When he has answered he passes the monkey (resetting the timer) on to the next player who must come up with another answer before the monkey laughs. This goes on until a player gives a wrong answer or the monkey laughs.

The player with the monkey moves his brain down the intelligence track. The loser is the first to reach the loser level.

Just like "Send aben videre!", but only 240 questions and slightly easier.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Electronic, Humor, Memory, Party Game, Real-time, Trivia

name: College Football
description:
College Football simulates an entire NCAA football season. The players are not playing against one another, just recreating a season and participating in its progress.

A schedule is preset using twenty of the top college football teams (which can be chosen and ranked by the players). All other teams are represented by a generic "unranked" team. A season is then played out for the ranked teams. The game scores are based on the teams' rankings; the better a team is ranked, the more likely it is do score well and win. Each game takes only a few seconds to resolve (using a specially-created deck of cards), and a scoreboard for each week is created using the results of these games. After each week, the players vote on where each ranked team should be newly ranked (invariably dropping some of them from the rankings entirely), and a new set of rankings is generated prior to the next week's play.

At the end of the season, the major bowl games are determined based on rankings and conference alignment, and then played to determine the final rankings.

There is an option for players to secretly select teams at the start of the season so that they are actually competing against one another.

Betting is optional, either with the basic game or the variant, but a "modified mean" must be used in calculating the rankings to prevent players from skewing the results by ranking their own favorites unreasonably high.

Good for an afternoon of fun for the college football fanatic. Lots of math, though!

name: Ocean Racing
description:
From the box (edited):

The object of the game is to sail from the start line up the board (passing all the buoys on their left-hand side) and back to cross the start line. The first yacht to do so is the winner.

The principle of the game is based on the behavior of an actual sailing vessel, and particular note should be taken of the wind direction which is denoted by the Wind Arrow positioned on the right of the playing board. The arrow head, in common with a weather vane, points in the direction from which the wind is coming. No vessel can sail directly into the wind. Vessels sailing at right angles to the wind are said to be reaching. Vessels with the wind from behind are said to be running.

name: Kvikke Krokodiller
description:
Each player starts with the tip of the nose of their own crocodile (4 different colors). The rest of the crocodiles are mixed and turned face down between the players. Youngest players starts by rolling the special die, which has 4 sad faces and 2 crocodiles. If the player rolls a crocodile, he may immediately start trying to collect his crocodile, by turning over a piece. The pieces have to match both color and place, although you will alway have two end of your crocodile open. If the piece match the player picks it, otherwise he has to turn it back. The player may continue to turn over pieces until another player rolls the crocodile. So you will always have one player collecting his crocodile, while the rest are rolling the die.

Whoever finishes their crocodile first wins.

name: Kartenspiele und Würfelspass
description: This is actually a set of materials with which over 125 different card and dice games can be played, complete with rules and score pads.

name: Top Dog
description:
According to Sid Sackson's "A Gamut of Games":

Two players take turns shaking six dogs each out of his or her half of a bone. If any are "sitting up" you can score for these, or set them aside and throw the others again for more points. Players can stop and score after any throw, or loose all if none sit up.
publishers: John N. Hansen Co., Inc., Saratoga Toys & Games

name: Tailgate Trivia: Ohio State Buckeye Fans
description:
Tailgate Trivia: Ohio State Buckeye Fan is a trivia based on The Ohio State University football history.

A player, designated the quarterback, reads a trivia question. The players or the quarterback chooses on of the following topics:

- Offense
- Defense & special teams
- Team Records
- Draft pick
- All-Americans
- Name & number.

Each topic may also include a bonus question.

The quarterback reads the question aloud to the other players. If a player can answer the question correctly, they receive 2 points. If they can also answer the bonus question, they receive 2 additional points. If no one can answer, the quarterback can then offer multiple choice answers to the question. If a player can answer after hearing the multiple choice options, they receive 1 point.

name: Turkeys Wild!
description:
According to Sid Sackson's "A Gamut of Games":

Poker with a special deck that includes six wild cards. Play for points instead of chips. Each winning hand has a value, which is multiplied by the number of "bets" or "gobbles".

name: Das Deutsche Tierschutzspiel
description:
The aim of the game is to bring your animals as fast as possible to your home and treat them well. The horse lives in the forest, the cat in its wooden box, the dog and the cock outside the house on the farm. During the game players have to deal with certain risk coming up (Illness, Thieves etc...). The player who is able to bring his four animals fastest on his farm wins the game.

Game contents:
1 board
15 friendly animal cards
15 unfriendly animal cards
18 inoculation certificates
120 fodder vouchers
16 animal figures
2 dice
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Frisko
description:
"The Roaring Game of the Barbary Coast"

A simple betting game using three dice and wooden "chits" numbered 1 through 6, as well as "Low/High" and "Odd/Even".

One person plays the "Frisker" (dice roller) while all of the other players bet on the outcome of the roll. Players can bet on individual numbers appearing (1 through 6), an Odd or Even combined total, a Low total (10 or under), or a High total (11 or higher). Betting is done with wooden chips which are purchased ahead of time.

Frisker pays even money for all successful bets and gets to keep all others. After ten throws, the roll of the Frisker is passed to the next player.

name: Fairytale Charms
description: A magical game for all little princesses! The game idea is to move the Fairy Godmother around the game board, carry out small challenges and collect charms in your own charm bracelet. Each time you succeed in carrying out a challenge – for example, you find the four-leaf-clover or end up with the bigger half of a wishbone – you can add a new charm in your bracelet. But watch out for the black cat that brings you bad luck: you can not win before you pass the cat on to some other player! The first princess to fill her bracelet with charms wins the game!

name: Battle of Salamis
description:
From the Spartan Magazine, #2.

Includes one rule pamphlet, one chart sheet, one map and 86 counters.

Scale is one unit = 25 ships.

name: WonderChess
description:
From the publisher:

"WonderChess features innovative prize fillable pieces and an instruction book. Making kids smarter in a wonder-filled way!"

This is a chess set specifically designed with the new/young player in mind. The game itself plays normally, but each piece has a base and a top portion which separates. The idea is to place a "prize" inside each and as the child captures a piece he/she gets the prize inside. (The game comes with some nice stickers as a start.)

The game also includes one of the best starter booklets I have seen.

name: Betting on Nature
description:
Each player in turn asks another player a question based on an anecdote about the life of a natural species.

Players bet on the answer they think is correct and try to win the pot.

name: La Vuelta Ciclista
description:
This is a cycling game devoted to "The Vuelta" (The Spanish equivalent of the "Tour de France").

The mechanism is an ultra-simple roll and move. Roll a die, move thet many spaces. There are some squares with special "abilities" (roll three dice, pick highest number, skip a turn,....). First one to finish wins the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Attaque: Jeu de rôle et de stratégie du Tour de France cycliste
description:
This is a rather complex bike racing simulation.

Each cyclist is determined by no less then 9 characteristics! Movement is determined by the roll of a die, but there are a lot of modifiers - weather (temperature, wind direction and wind speed), the racers characteristics, teammates, road, events,..

The material and rules present allow simulation of almost any race.

The track consists of different stretches of road you can put together as you like. The game comes with all necessary files in electronic format, so you can make additional track pieces.

name: Nuts to You
description: In this game, as one of the four animals, you try and collect the most nuts; the unique mechanism is that there is a talk device with a strip that will say a prescribed sentence back to you. It works sort of like a pull string dummy that has several phrases it can say. Interesting plastic peanuts you collect too ;-)

name: Boston Marathon Game
description:
The Official Boston Marathon Game. Approved by the Boston Athletic Association. 1978. Perl Products Company. 522 S. Sepulveda Blvd., Los Angeles, Ca. 90049.

Race 26 miles, 385 yards with thousands of other runners in the privacy of your own home!

This game is a "spin the spinner and move toward the finish" game. The board has some neat mid-1970's jogging craze comic artwork.

There's a vicious unpredictable dog to avoid, a press bus, bowls of beef stew, 1600 other runner tokens, a laurel wreath for the winner, a police escort, etc.

A funny game that you don't see too often.

name: Good Heavens!
description:
From the back of the box:
"54 playing cards each include a question, answer, and informative paragraph as well as a list of possible answers to questions on other cards. A combination of luck and memory makes one a winner! Playing rules will stimulate fun and active participation among all players. No background in astronomy is needed to begin play. 2-6 players or teams. Ages 10 and up."

name: Dora the Explorer Block Game
description:
A tower building block game consisting of 48 wooden blocks (similar to Jenga) with two methods of play specifically for children. Designed for Ages 3 - 6.

In one game you remove the blocks one by one from the tower and watch it tremble and eventually fall.

In the other, three of the blocks are stamped with pictures of Backpack, Map and Boots, characters from Dora the Explorer. Mix them up in the tower and try to find them by pulling out blocks without causing the tower to tumble.
publishers: Four Four Four Limited, Viacom International

name: Walt Disney World Game
description:
A rather simple version of the Disneyland themed games, stripped to its essentials.

Players Start at Sleeping Beauty's castle, and use a spinner to indicate spaces moved. They then have to visit 8 Disney attractions and collect souvenirs from each. The player to collect all eight chits first wins.

Components:

- Board

- 4 cardboard counters with plastic bases: Mickey, Minnie, Donald & Goofy.

- 5 souvenir chits (1 surplus which may be used to accommodate an additional player) of each of 8 attractions: Mr. Lincoln, Mickey's Band, It's A Small World, Haunted Mansion, Pirates Of The Caribbean, Mad Tea Party, Bear Jamboree & Space Mountain.

- 1 "It's A Small World" spinner
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Keep On Rolling
description:
A "Spicy Dice" game.

Keep On Rolling is a game for 2 or more players that requires a set of Spicy Dice to play. Players push their luck in order to be the first to reach 250 points. Red pips double the scored points for a given die and mating all 6 dice once again doubles your score or allows you to press your luck and Keep On Rolling.

name: Batman & Robin: Put Mr. Freeze on Ice Card Game
description:
Objective:
