Enjoy the experience of touring through one of the most scenic and exciting states in the nation, learning interesting facts about prominent people, places, sports and recreation along the way. You can impress your friends and family with what you already know. When you finish Le'Tour, you will be an expert on Colorado. We might even call you a native.

Le'Tour is designed for 2 to 40 players. It is well suited to be a team game with up to four teams of players.

name: Texas Renaissance Festival Game
description: The object of the game is to be the first to enter the Royal Castle by winning a series of contests and challenges.

name: Steve Garvey's Superstar Baseball
description: Steve Garvey's Superstar Baseball is a baseball-themed dice game not a baseball simulation. The game is divided into five parts: hitting ground balls, bunting, hit and run play, base running, and power hitting. In every case, a player takes a turn by rolling the four dice and checking the appropriate table for the results. A player could score one or two points each turn. The player who has more points at the end of the game wins. The game comes with magnetic ball and magnetic players, dice, and instructions.

name: SHA-EE: The Game of Destiny
description: SHA-EE is a path-building game. Players start at the edge of the board and place triangular tiles to extend their paths towards the center space. There are restrictions on when each section of the board can be entered. Some spaces must be occupied by the players' small guard pieces; occupying some of these spaces requires rolling the special die, and occupation of others can be challenged, which also requires rolling the die. The game ends when someone occupies the center space with their king, but the winner of the game is the one who scores the most points from their occupied spaces, not necessarily the player who reaches the center.

name: 'Bouta Face
description: Bouta Face is a matching-memory card game (It is About Faces). The specialized card deck has 11 different colorful funny and amusing faces. Most card games use one side of the card - Bouta Face uniquely uses both sides on every turn. There are 3 game variations - a beginners version, an advanced version and a solitaire game. All three have the objective of matching as many identical faces in pairs as possible. The person who collects the most pairs wins. The games are easy to learn, and hugely entertaining. Unlike any card game you have ever played. Recommended Ages 7 and up, 2 to 4 players.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Humor, Memory, Party Game

name: Fire Chief
description: The Fire Chief Board Game comes from See Right Games and was produced in 1957. A game where players try to protect the local neighborhood from fires by walking on the paths throughout the neighborhood using a spinner and then encountering problems using another spinner. Whoever does best at protecting the neighborhood wins the game.

name: Who Took The Cookie from the Cookie Jar? Game
description:
From the back of the tin:

"The ever popular children's rhyme "Who took the cookie from the cookie jar" is now a game that even pre-readers can enjoy. Players travel around the cookie board and must either "give a cookie", "take a cookie", or say "not me"! Players actually choose their cookies from the special cookie jar shaped package. First player to collect 3 unique cookie playing pieces wins!"

- No Reading Required
- Promotes Interaction
- Easy to Learn and Play

name: Jomack
description:
"The most versatile game of the century

It's an exciting and fast paced word game where everyone has an equal chance to play every turn. It's a game you can play with your grandparents or your grandchildren and everyone in between. Best of all, it's a family fun game where the only limit is your imagination."

In the base game, three random letter cards are revealed, and first player to call out a word containing all three of the letters gets to add it to their score sheet. First player to 11 words wins.

There are five other variant rule sets included, such as "Point Jomack", where longer words are better - you get additional points for each added letter.

name: The Mummy Mystery Game
description: THE MUMMY MYSTERY GAME by Hasbro © 1963 from the Universal Pictures movie of the same name. Lid features stalking Mummy art with text that says "Explore The Ancient Crypts Of Egypt." The game board shows a Mummy walking through Egyptian ruins. Game includes 20 "Crypt" cards, 4 Mummy playing pieces and 4 wooden markers.

name: Creeps!
description:
Manufacturers Blurb: Creeps! The game that strikes terror at the heart! Pick up a dagger and strike the vampire in his coffin... but tread carefully or he'll awake with a flash and a screech!
A spine chilling game for children over 7 years and adults too!

A game of chance and skill - pit your wits against the Vampire. Get him before he gets you!

Game Summary: Players race to move one of their daggers to the centre of the board and slay the vampire. Each player begins the game with 5 daggers, and places one of them on the starting 'foot-print' at the beginning of the game. Each turn every player gets 6 movement points to share between his daggers (ie move 1 dagger forward 6 footprints, or 2 daggers 3 footprints each, or any combination up to a total of 6). You can 'leapfrog' your own daggers, (but may never have 2 daggers on the same footprint) and at the end of each move the dagger is 'stabbed' into the board. When a dagger is placed in one of the randomly selected footprints the Vampire will let out a bloodcurdling scream causing that dagger to be removed from the game. Players have to remember which footprints will wake the Vampire and avoid them for the rest of the game. The first player to reach the centre of the board and stab his dagger into the heart of the Vampire wins!
publishers: Action Games and Toys Ltd, Action GT

name: Back Talk
description: You move along a board and you draw cards. On the cards are words you've got the draw on the back of a team member. He has to guess the word.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Humor, Party Game

name: Get That License
description: This is a travel game that teaches players to receognize license plates for "the 48 States and District of Columbia." Players travel the "lower 48" collecting license plates when passing through the capitol city of a state, each of which may only be visited once per game. The license plates have varying point values depending on the difficulty in reaching the state. A die roll of six requires the player to draw a "Detour" card which alters the players movement in various ways. When all license plates have been claimed, players add up their scores to determine the winner.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Pass The Ewe
description:
There are five suits in this game: The 12 royal cards (J, Q, K) of all four traditional suits make one suit; they don’t count for their normal suits. The remaining cards in the other suits (A to 10 in spades, hearts, clubs, and diamonds) make the other four suits.

If you’re starting a hand, you must play one or more cards of only one suit (S, H, C, D, royals). Play passes to your left.

When play passes to you, you may pass or play. If you pass, play passes to your left. If you play, you must play a homogeneous set of cards that beats what was most recently played. The rank of the card you play is irrelevant, but the number of cards you play and their suit is relevant.

Suit Ranking:
Hearts beat spades and clubs. Clubs beat hearts and diamonds. Diamonds beat clubs and royals. Royals beat diamonds and spades. Spades beat royals and hearts.

If the most recent play was one heart, you can play one club, or one spade, or two hearts. You can not play more than what you need to beat what was played; you can’t play three or more hearts or two or more clubs or spades.

Short play example:
Alice starts a hand by playing two clubs. Bob plays three clubs. Cathy passes. Dan plays three diamonds. Alice passes. Bob passes. Cathy plays three royals. Dan plays four royals. Alice plays four diamonds. Bob plays four clubs. Cathy plays four hearts. Dan passes. Alice plays five hearts. Bob, Cathy, and Dan all pass and Alice takes the hand.

If play passes back to you and you were the last player to play, you get the ewe totem and all of the cards played go face-down into your Wool Pile. You get a one-point bonus to your score. The hand is over.

If all players have cards left in hand, the player to the left of the player with the ewe starts the next hand. If at least one player is out of cards the round is over. If you have cards in hand at the end of a round, you lose one point for every card in your hand. If you have the ewe at the end of a round, you get a two-point bonus to your score.

If the round is over, count the number of cards in your Wool Pile and have the scorekeeper add that to your score. If one or more players have 100 points or more, the game is over. If the game is not over, collect and shuffle all of the cards.

If you have the ewe at the end of the game, you get a 5-point bonus to your score.

name: Zahnputz-Memo
description:
Premiered at Essen 2000.

Intended for Ages 4 and up

Equipment: 26 card pairs displaying food, 1 pair of family cards, 1 tooth, 1 toothbrush, 1 bacterium, 1 Decoder, tooth cleaning glossary

In the first game children gather together pairs of food cards and take turns stating whether the food is healthy for teeth or contains too much sugar. By training the decoder on a red point on the cards, they can determine whether they are correct or not.

The second game is played more like traditional Memory, but in addition, after claiming the pair the child must state whether the food is tooth-friendly or not.

The family cards are always taken automatically without further tests being applied.

Tooth, toothbrush and bacterium are used to indicate the various food statuses.

Received 2 out of a possible 6 dice pips at Spielphase, due to ambiguities of the cards.

name: USA på boks
description:
(Translated from publisher's site in Norwegian)
How much do you actually know about the USA? About the USA's culture, geography, showbiz and famous people? In this game you really get to test your knowledge - and you are guaranteed to learn something new.

The game is divided into three categories; Stars and Stripes (with geography, culture and history) - where all the states are present, Showtime USA (sports and entertainment) - where Entertainer includes miming tasks to be solved on time. Every card of questions has a picture and a question relating to it. All the pictures depict the USA, and make the game a wonderful visual experience! The content in the Star and Stripes category is based on the high school curriculum. The game has been been developed by the experienced educational book writer Clara Amland.

name: Leela
description: From the back of the box: Designed by Hindu Sages over two thousand years ago and the precursor to the game "chutes and ladders," Leela is nothing less than the game of life, providing insight into our own consciousness and a key to divine knowledge. One or more can play the game of Leela, using only the book and game board, a die, and a significant object that belongs to the player (such as a ring) to serve as his or her symbol during the game...
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Pharomyd
description:
PHAROMYD is played on a triangular board using 16 four-sided "pyramids" (tetrahedrons) - each side has a different marker colour/symbol on it. Players move pieces with the aim of preventing other players from moving, but can only move pieces with their symbol showing. Each piece can be moved by 3 players - the three sides showing - but players can also convert pieces so that their own symbol shows.

A move consists of rolling a "pyramid" in one of 3 directions, tipping it along an edge onto a new face. There are patterns to form - such as sandwiching a "pyramid" between two other "pyramids" with identical faces showing toward each other.

Any player unable to move on their turn is eliminated and the game ends when only 1 player is left in the game.

name: Västkustspelet
description: Västkustspelet is a trivia game (basically a Trivial Pursuit: Genus Edition clone), with questions about the Swedish west coast.

name: Powarvasion
description:
From the box:

"In POWARVASION(tm), two warring players battle to capture the other's government or three major cities. Players alternate moving one of their armed forces pieces until the war is over. These fighting forces move and capture in any direction up to their maximum range. Strategy and skill are the keys to victory. Players set hidden defensive traps, carry out hit and run raids and multiple captures, set up formidable geographical barriers, and launch nuclear attacks. POWARVASION(tm) is easy to learn, fun to play, and a superior war game challenge!"

The board (with a sample setup, less the hidden traps and presumably cities) is shown on the back of the box. 9x9 square grid, Country Capital (white house), ICBM and Bomber (counters?) look like the King & Queen in chess, flanked by two sets of helicopter, artillery and jet pieces in the knight/bishop/rook configs. 3 tanks and 6 infantry round out the pawn row (tanks at ends and center). From the board, it looks as if the next two rows you can choose where to set your 3 mountains; single river, lake and forest pieces, as well as two minefields and a missile site, along with between 6-9 "hidden" pieces (one side has 6, the other 9).

The side of the box has a picture of Col. James Jacobson, USAF ret., with a recommendation: "Powarvasion ...is an easy game to play, a thinking man's game of unmatched realism!"

name: Hockeypoker
description: From the box: "Hockeypoker will fascinate the whole family, make up your teams, play cards on ice and score! Beware of the face-off! Outplay your opponents with strategy and speed! Move the puck to your advantage by playing your hand of offensive and defensive players, goalies and star players". Contents include gameboard, instructions, a deck of cards and five "pucks".

name: Snagglepuss:  Fun at the Picnic Game
description: Memory children's game featuring the cartoon characters Snagglepuss, Yogi Bear, Boo-Boo Bear and Huckleberry Hound.

name: Marblix
description: The players tries to land their MARBLIX as close to the center of the play area as possible while also attempting to knock away an opponent's well-placed MARBLIX, just like curling.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Collectible Components, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Pirates, Racing

name: Monster Quest
description:
From the Website...

"Monster Quest is a fun and exciting game, with nine years of play testing by fantasy gamers. If you like dungeons and a dragon or two than you will love a game of Monster Quest. The game doesn't take days or weeks to prepare it's ready to go in minutes right out of the box. Monster Quest is a mythological board game that leads a player through a magical land of action and adventure. Monster Quest has 226 spaces on the board and 450 cards. There are Spell cards, Wisdom cards, Map cards, Monster cards, and even Property cards that can be bought during the game. The cards are one of the ways that a player develops their character. Also, the cards give the player the ability to move about the land of Monster Quest rather than relying solely on the chance of the dice.

There are 12 different parts to the game-board, a main trail that connects all of the different parts of the game-board together, a Town Adventure, a Dungeon, six Inner trails, and three Outer trails.

Each player has a pegboard to keep track of their Hit Points (HP), Armor Class (AC), Platinum Pieces (PP), Gold Pieces (GP), Silver Pieces (SP), Jewels, and the Experience (Exp.) that a player will gain during the game.

Monster Quest uses two sets of dice, two six-sided and two eight-sided. The dice are used to Battle Monsters, win treasure, and move about the land of Monster Quest.

A game of Monster Quest can last anywhere from three to five hours depending on the level of difficulty you wish to play. Monster Quest can be played by two to four players. There are six jewels in the game protected by monsters; a player must collect all six jewels to win the game. Monster Quest is a whole world on one board where strategy is key.

Beyond the City Gate treasure awaits in dark Caves, along Wooded Trails through the Emerald Forest on Shipyard Docks across the Black Sea to thirst in the Desert wandering the Foothills to the Mountains of Doom on your way to the King?s Castle to save the Princess. BEWARE of the Dungeon on your quest young squire and if you have what it takes the jewels can be yours."
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Titeuf Le Jeu
description:
Titeuf is a well known animated series comic character in France. In this game you help him and his gang passing a day in school. You will have to master hilarious challenges.

Beside 220 cards and a dice there will be also a mini ball launcher and a basket to throw the ball in.

name: Dandy Candy Game
description: Extrapolated from a Games Gone By article. Game is based a lot on CANDYLAND. Board is 13 X 20 and features places like Lollypop Land, Candy Cane Lane and Gumdrop Islands. The game included 4 wooden pawns, a candycane spinner. Object of the game was to make your way through the maze and finish at the candy store. First one there won the game.

name: Holidays in Switzerland
description: A simple roll-and-move game wherein players travel through Switzerland, trying to be the first to complete the route. There are a few additional random elements, including cash (which players must produce at various points along the path) as well as a few talent contests (such as singing the first verse of a song, and moving a number of spaces depending upon how well one has sung) or answering some trivia questions about the current town.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Roll / Spin and Move, Singing

name: A Game About The United Nations
description: Players compete to fill seats on the U.N. security council. Combines political theme with monopoly-like roll and move mechanics.

name: Spyhunting
description:
Spyhunting is a 2-player strategy game whereby one player acts as the hunter and one player is hunted a.k.a. the spy.

This game can be played with standard equipment (checkerboard) from the average gamer collection in addition to some non-standard dice.

The spy’s objective is to travel from one corner to the opposite corner and back without being “shot.” The hunter’s objective is to “shoot” the spy before he or she accomplishes his or her objective.

This game was a Top 11 finalist in the 2002 Board Game Design Competition called "Simultaneous Action Design" awarded by About.Com.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Print & Play, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: The American Civil War 1861-1865
description: A brief description from inside the book is as follows: "The A to Z Rules for the American Civil War is the second in series of fast playing rules for 15mm and 25mm miniatures. It is compatible with all basing systems and can be played on a regimental or brigade level. It will enable you to lay a short scenario in three hours or recreate a massive day long battle in brigade scale within five to six days.

name: The Campaigns of Napoleon
description: The A to Z Rules, the Campaigns of Napoleon 1796-1815, is the fourth in a series od fast playing rules for historical miniatures. It is compatible with all basing systems and can be played on a battalion, regimental, or brigade scale. It will enable you to play a short scenario in three hours or recreate a massive day long battle in brigae scale within five to eight hours. The heart of the rules are the intiative and action allocation systems. Combined with morale variables, these are the most critical areas determinging the flow of the game. They are also areas of great flexibility and changes can be made to recreate local conditions, commander capabilities, or scenario anomalies.

name: Biggles
description: This is a rummy variant themed on James Bigglesworth, better known as "Biggles", who is a fictional British WWI pilot and adventurer created by W. E. Johns. In addition to the rummy-based play, the game incorporates some storytelling through the artwork on the cards depicting Biggles in a variety of adventures.

name: Business Game Delft
description:
This is a board game published in 1996 to celebrate Delft's 750 years as a cultural city. It appears to be published/supported by a host of Dutch business, particularly those based in Delft. One of the businesses is Jumbo games. Several forewords from the various companies involved in the game are found in the rules book.

The board is a 12 X 12 square grid superimposed on a map of Delft. The object of the game is to place tiles on the board, with the coordinates determined by rolling two dice (with opportunities for two re-rolls). When a square of four tiles is on the board, it is considered completed and is turned over to show an 'object worth seeing'. Rolling doubles allows one to roll a special die, which could result in an extra turn, being allowed to place two tiles anywhere on the board, or missing the next turn.

The game ends when someone has completed five objects worth seeing. Scoring points is based on where the tiles in completed objects lie. The player with the most points wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: The Game of Football
description:
The Game of Football produced by Parker Brothers in 1880 features a picture of young boys playing a game that looks a bit like sandlot football. The game comes with a number of colored pieces that represent players and by jumping over players each team tries to score goals.

As a version of late-1800s football, this game would be completely different from the same-named Game of Football from 1948, as the rules of the physical game developed significantly in the intervening 70 years.

name: Die Wilden Hühner und die Liebe
description: Game tie-in to the German 2007 film of the same name based on the book by the writer of "Inkheart", Cornelia Funke. The title translates as "Wild Chickens and Love." The description at Amazon.de makes it sound like a romantic polygon of Sprotte, Melanie, Frieda, Wilma, Trude, and Maik. The players try to collect the correct pairs. Contents: 5 collecting maps, 35 cards, 4 three wooden meeples, and 49 wild chicken markers. For Ages 8 - 13.

name: Win A Card
description: Win-A-Card Board Game was put out by Milton Bradley in 1969 and came with 1968 Topps Baseball cards. Football and Non Sports cards were also included. The cards came in clear cellophane packs. The game box reads "Contains a generous supply.", probably between 50-70 baseball cards, and various amount of the other sports, and non sports cards. The 1968 Topps cards that were included with the game are of a different variation to the regular issued Topps cards. The backs of the cards are a bright yellow color as opposed to orange backs. Game included a spinner which was used to determine if trades of cards between players took place.

name: Red Deer on Board
description: This is a Monopoly style game based on the Red Deer Region of Alberta Canada. The game was produced in conjunction with Habitat for Humanity and its proceeds benefitted that organization.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Nav-O-Strat
description:
Board game of naval/air warfare with capture of islands/bases.

Game features perhaps one of the largest boxes in the history of game publishing--24 1/4 inches by 18 1/4 inches by one-and-a-half inches. The hard-mounted board is twice this size. The single combat chart is the size of the box.

The box top features a reproduction of a hand-drawn charcoal-pencil picture of an aircraft carrier flight deck and island with crewmen on deck, with ships and planes in the background along with yellow-and-red shell bursts, muzzle flashes and black smoke plume.

Rules are contained in a single-folded 8 1/2 inch by 11 inch sheet.

Components include Board, Battle Chart, twenty cards (numbered from One to Ten), two dice and two fleets of miniature vac-u-formed ships in red and blue, plus eight injection-molded miniature 105 mm guns in silver.

Board is a grid of one-inch white-outlined squares on a blue sea. Along one side of the board is a display for each carrier deck plus a Dry Dock and Shipyard display for each player.

Along each baseline is a Home Base and Airfield. A sixteen-square island with an Airfield and four fort zones occupies the center of each half of the game board.

Each Fleet consists of two Aircraft Carriers, 3 Battleships, 4 Landing Barges, 5 Planes, 2 Cruisers, 2 Destroyers, and 4 Submarines.

The "Battle Chart" has 26 columns, one for each possible attacker/defender type combination, plus a column for "Units of equal strength." Ten results are provided for each column including outcomes such as Sunk, Damaged, Return to Shipyard, Retreats, Escapes, and more.

Victory is achieved by either sinking the enemy Fleet or capturing the enemy's Island Base.

Toomey Toys was located in Harrisburg, PA.
categories: Fighting, Nautical, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Run the Guns
description:
Miniature wargame rules for naval actions in the American Civil War, intended for 15mm scale figures and miniature ships but also usable with 10mm and, with some record keeping, 1/600 or smaller ship miniatures (with player-provided movement/range conversions).

Rules cover armored vessels, steam and wind-powered ships, submarines, ramming, ship vs. fortification, and boarding actions. Leadership, crew quality, various weight of guns, damage control, grounding, fires, about 14 pages of rules and a two-sided removable card with game tables.
categories: American Civil War, Fighting, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame

name: Let's Go to McDonald's Game
description: Let's Go To McDonald's Game is a child's game. Players race along a colorful track to be the first to reach McDonald's. The game teaches color recognition and matching, turn taking, and fair play. Each player controls a "Happy Meal Toy" character (Grimace, Birdie the Early Bird, The Hamburgler, and of course, Ronald McDonald himself) and advance along the path avoiding obstacles such as a duck crossing, an open manhole, a skunk, and a broken fire hydrant. Randomly placed tiles along the way will either send you forward or backwards on the path because as the game itself states, "Anything can happen on the way to McDonald's!" The first player to reach the Golden Arches is the winner.

name: Bikee
description:
From Games et al and used with permission:
This is a truly fun game manufactured by C W Faulkner & Co in 1899 and is a race game covering the, then, popular hobby of cycling. Falulkner produced a series of games similar to Bikee called the ‘Upidee Series’ Cards are laid out to provide the course and the use of a teetotum provides the means of movement. This game consists of up to six cyclists, two dice, the rules and 20 illustrated course cards. The bottom of the box lists other games by Faulkner.

Note: Rules stipulate teetotum but d6 die is pictured with game in BGG gallery. Another ebay sale has images showing a four-sided teetotum with sides numbered 1-4.
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Rhyme-n-Tyme
description: This is a party game focused on the mechanic of team's guessing humorous rhymed pairs of words. In alternating turns, each team's clue giver selects a card and begins describing the two word rhyme using words and/or pantomime (like in charades). When the correct rhyme is guessed, the clue giver draws another card, with the goal being to guess as many rhymes in 60 seconds. Examples of rhyming pairs of words include: "Pooch Smooch," "Moose Juice," "Jet Sweat" and so on.
publishers: EEL, Inc., Vintage Sports Cards, Inc.

name: Heroes of Asfar: The Bag of Chaos
description: This is the second expansion for Heroes of Asfar, an entertainingly chaotic game in which you try to subdue an opponent's character cards, thereby scoring enough points to win. This expansion contains 4 new character cards, 35 additional play deck cards, including such cards as the Flying Iron Cestus, the Awesome Ring of Wishes, and the Bag of Chaos.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting

name: Draim Arena
description:
A new Swedish CCG.

Novel or unusual features include non-rectangular cards(!), comparatively small decks, and combat resolution by special twelve-sided "tactics" and "combat" dice.

Official homepage: http://www.draim.com/arena
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Verhext!
description:
Text from the introduction in the rules:
The witches keenly stare at the magic bowl.... in a few seconds the magic symbols will appear. The witches are as quiet as mice and even the cauldron has stopped bubbling. Finally the symbols can be clearly recognized. Immediately the witches yell their magic spells, as only the quickest witch to shout the correct spell will become the new superior witch!

This is one of Haba's Tumble-dice games, characterized by using dice in a domed container, a clever way of ensuring the dice don't get separated and lost.

The contents of the game are:
- A clear-domed tumbler with seven red six-sided dice (each die with 2 cats, 2 bats and 2 brooms) and one die with one, two or three black dots, or one, two or three red dots on its six sides.
- One orange wooden witch meeple
- 30 cards showing either a scene with many witches or a scene with one witch. The backs of the card show the face of one of three different witches.
- The rules.

The tumbler is placed in the centre and seven cards are dealt face up around the tumbler. The witch piece is placed on any card and during the game only moves in a clockwise direction. The player whose turn it is shakes the dice and all players simultaneously try to see what spell is indicated and which they must recite. The spell to recite is determined by where the witch lands. The die with one to three spots in two colours determines where the witch lands. If it is a card with many witches, the players must recite the spell corresponding to the type of animal that appears the most times on the dice. If it is a card with one witch, the players must recite the spell corresponding the type of animal that appears the least number of times on the dice. The first player to recite the correct spell gets to keep the card that the witch was standing on. The witch then moves clockwise the number of steps indicated on the pipped die and a new card is placed in the space vacated by the witch.

The winner is the first player to get three of the same witch (on the card backs) or any five witches.
The rules provide for a professional variation, where the colour of the dots, either black or red, on the pipped die makes a difference. The cards have little signposts with a black star or red mushroom. The movement of the witch will then be in the direction of the red star or red mushroom accordingly .

name: Reclame quiz: Editie 2002
description:
2 to 4 teams of minimum of 2 people play against each other. They try to get as much points as possible by finishing assignments.

The team trows a die and the number decides what assignment they get. For every successfully finished assignment the team gets the assignment-card, which counts as 1 point. The green, red and blue cards are normal cards, the golden cards are special "Gouden Loeki"-cards.

The assignments can be slogans, drawing, trivia ect. The game is themed around popular commercials.

name: Jack and the Beanstalk
description:
From the back of the box:
Learn about shapes in this fun game with a popular fairy talk theme. Feel for the magic shape 'bean' in the bag and if it matches one of your cards you can build the beanstalk for Jack to climb. You'll have to avoid the giant to win!
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Educational, Fantasy, Math, Novel-based
mechanics: Modular Board, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Animal Rummy
description: Rummy style game from the 60's.
publishers: Cartamundi, eeBoo, Melissa & Doug, Russell Manufacturing Company, ThinkFun, Western Publishing Company, Whitman

name: Scrabble Head to Head
description:
A new and exciting way to play with words.

In this ever-changing, two player game of fast & furious world building fun, players race to make the highest scoring word from the 7 SCRABBLE letter cubes. it's a real tug of words! You must think quickly - once your opponent calls, you only have 15 seconds to find a higher scoring word - spot it, and you get to move the shuttle one space towards your opponent.

Suddenly all the cubes move, and there's a new set of letters !

name: Barbarian Hordes
description: Barbarian Hordes is a card and dice game depicting the clash of Empires and Barbarian Nations in Europe circa 400 AD. Simple system of raising armies and conquering your opponents' territories. Be you Roman, Hun, or Goth, crush your foes and take all that you see by force.

name: Yankee Pedlar
description: This simple children's game was hand-colored! Featured in the Liman Collection of board games at the New York Historical Society.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: The English Civil War
description:
The English Civil war is a Card game for 2 players simulating the British Civil Wars 1642-1649. One player is the Parliamentarians and the other is the Royalists. Simultaneous turns. The nature of confrontations are determined by whether players choose to attack or defend. Players accumulate troops counters and fight each other for territory tokens. Battles are resolved with dice and card play. Flavor is provided by the cards. A free copy of the rules is available at:
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/TECW.html
categories: Card Game, Civil War, Pike and Shot, Print & Play

name: Monopoly: Michael Graves Design
description: Michael Graves retools the classic game with a new look. Includes 12 hotels, 32 houses and 6 Michael Graves Monopoly tokens. Tokens include desk clock, desk lamp, suitcase, teapot, blender, and, toaster. Houses and Hotels are made of rubber and the board has a silvery prismatic finish. The money is semi see-through (almost like a parchment paper). All of the pieces store neatly in a plastic cast that slides into its own carrying case. The game fully stored measures 14 inches length x 8.5 inches width x 3.5 inches height. Great for travel!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Round Britain Trivia
description:
There are three variants that can be played.

Game 1, as individuals, players take it in turns to be the question master for one card each. Highest score wins.

Game 2, as individuals, each player rolls a die and is asked the question on the card by the player to the right. Play passes to the right. Highest score after an agreed number of rounds wins.

Game 3, in two equal teams, each player in the team will receive a question and decide whether to answer individually, (scoring two points,) or to confer, (scoring one point.) The team with the highest score after an agreed number of rounds wins.

name: Ballbuster
description:
Ballbuster: A Game of Skill for Two Players

Object: The first player to form a row of six of his/her marbles is the winner.

A fast-paced game of skill and chance for two players.

Ballbuster features an original red plastic 3 dimensional game-board with special chutes to transport marbles between players.

Players begin the game with a set of marbles and a pair of dice. Rolling the dice in turn, players place marbles strategically to either make a row or block the other player.

The game can be won in three rolls of the dice, or it can last up to 20 minutes.
publishers: Game Box, Inc., Holdsworth Thos & Sons

name: Monopolist
description:
From the publisher:
On this board the great struggle between capital and labor can be fought out to the satisfaction of all parties, and, if the players are successful, they can beat the Monopolists and become Monopolists themselves.

Players compete to form monopolies while avoiding embarrassment, loss of credit, unlucky ventures, and impaired capital.

name: Kamp Killjoy
description:
Kamp Killjoy is the second game in the Psychos and Slashers series of card games, designed to recreate the silliest aspects of 'B' horror films. You become a psychotic killer stalking innocent victims, competing with other mad slashers to acquire the choicest morsels . . . This second game in the series is designed to be played either on its own, or in combination with the earlier game, Suburban Slasher.

The two games were also sold together as the Psychos and Slashers Deluxe Set.

Related to / Can be combined with:

Suburban Slasher, Psychos and Slashers Volume One
Psychotic Settings, Psychos and Slashers Volume Three
categories: Card Game, Horror, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Boxer Rebellion
description: Wargame depicting the Boxer Rebellion. Unusual Setting and Rules. Players are various foreign armies racing each other to the Legation neighborhood in the middle of Hong Kong. Players fight Chinese Army and Rebel Forces on the way there, who are only revealed by scouting. Counters and Map are provided.

name: Edmontonopoly
description:
From the box:

It's EdmontonOpoly... the most exciting board game of the year! Budding tycoons can now buy and sell the most established business, landmarks, tourist attractions and restaurants in Edmonton with a simple roll of the dice in this fun filled - exciting new board game!

name: The Howard Hughes Game
description:
In The Howard Hughes Game players move via die roll on a two-dimensional grid, drawing or trading cards when they land on the appropriate spaces. The goal is to get cards of the different types (Luck, Inheritance, and Corporate Know-How) for each of the eight phases of Hughes' life (as defined by the game) in turn. The phases are entered via "doors" on the board and the cards are turned in for money, which is tracked on a small board for each player. In true Hughes style, players may purchase injunctions to prevent movement through certain areas of the board. The object is to amass $2.5 billion dollars, the publisher's estimate of Hughes' fortune at the time.

In addition to the rules, the "Study Guide" booklet contains 21 pages of material on the life and investments of Howard Hughes and an extensive bibliography.

Although the name "Urban Systems" does not appear on the game, this is presumably the game in the case Rosemont Enterprises, Inc. v. Urban Systems, Inc. (72 Misc.2d 788, 789-90, 340 N.Y.S.2d 144, 145-46 [Sup.Ct.], modified, 42
App.Div.2d 544, 345 N.Y.S.2d 17 [App.Div.1973]). This case resulted in a judgement for Hughes against the game publisher, requiring them to withdraw the game from sale.

name: Triple Crown
description:
Each player uses pieces of a different colour.

On each of his turns a player rolls four dice. The value of one of the dice is taken as the ROW NUMBER. Two other dice together are the COLUMN number. The left over die is the scoring die. The cross section between ROW and COLUMN must be vacant to set the scoring die. Now if there are more Tiles adjacent to the new one (regardless of the colour) the you score. If there are tiles of your colour you´ll get some bonuses.

The game ends, when all players can not place one legal legal tile anymore. Player with highest score wins

name: Fantasy Island Rails
description:
A web-published variant of the well-known Empire Builder system by Mayfair Games. This game takes place on an eight piece modular map representing a group of islands. The area covered is smaller than the usual Empire Builder game and the terrain is extremely limited. It is limited to only 2-3 players.

The game can be downloaded here:
http://www.zahag.de/MMsKSg/rails/fir/main.html
mechanics: Crayon Rail System, Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Travel Tribond Kids
description:
Be the first to reach 15 points. Earn points by solving a clue set of three items with a common "bond."

Travel edition includes 250 clue sets on 50 cards, one card sleeve, score board and scoring pegs.

name: Don't Step on the Croc, Doc
description: This is an action children's game where each player has the role of an adventurer trying to cross a rope bridge to retrieve bars of gold. To retrieve the gold from the middle of setup, a player will have to move his piece across the heads of sleeping crocodiles, any of which could wake up if the player's not careful.

name: Jurassic Quest
description:
This is a game from Wild Goose that involves dinosaurs. There can be two to four players. You must avoid hot lava, endless swamps, and a bottomless tar pit. You must also build a T-Rex puzzle and answer questions. The first to reach the top of the volcano is the winner. This is a fun game with a lot of scientific information.

Ages 8 and up

Original Game Contents:

- Gameboard
- Instruction sheet
- 4 dinosaur pieces
- standard six-sided die
- 1 Disaster die (lightning bolt, T-Rex and 4 blank sides)
- 132 Question cards
- 33 Disaster cards
- 4 T-Rex puzzles (six pieces each)
- A pull-together volcano
- Sheet of static-cling lava pieces

'Survival is the name of this dinosaur game'. Wild Goose Co. promises 'Real science, real fun' and offers several high-quality sets to prove it
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Gemstones
description:
A strategy game of selective acquisition! The modular gameboard consists of 15 black acrylic hexagon rings, 3" diameter. Each "cave" holds two gems drawn at random from the velvet bag. Your goal is to collect 3 different types of gems on each turn, from three caves adjacent in a straight line. A wild card (clear stone) lets you collect a fourth, or alter the board. Six kinds of gems (102 in all) with varying values and quantities to collect with careful planning. Refill the caves from the bag after each turn and mark the harvested hollows with 3 black stones. At least one of your three caves must contain a black stone. Tally your hoard when the bag is empty. Most novel feature—the current player nominates who plays next! Don't worry, each player gets a turn in every round. Fascinating play for 1 to 5 players, Ages 8 and up.

http://www.gamepuzzles.com/abstrct2.htm#Gem

name: Pushers & Pimps
description:
This is a game that is inspired by Monopoly and is about the hard core streets of Copenhagen in Denmark, will you be one of the largest drug syndicates or will you send out your hoes and your pimps.

The game was only produced in 1500 copies, with the help from local shops and organizations.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Coggle
description:
This Boggle version has all the principles of the original, but comes with 6 new kinds of dice: thematic ones.
Each thematic dice has a word that restricts the valid words you can find. For example: rivers, insects, cities, names, professions, colors, etc.
publishers: Capiépa Éditeur: Jeux Éducatifs, Clipper, Miro Company, Palitoy Ltd., Parker Brothers

name: Boney Head
description:
This is an action/dexterity game that has players compete to remove glow in the dark bones from a plastic skull without disturbing it.

From the publisher: "Boney Head keeps all his spare bones in his head, your job is to remove them. The bigger the bone the bigger the points. If you disturb Boney. he'll shriek and laugh so hard it just might wake the dead!"

name: Pit Fighter: Fantasy Arena – Scenario Pack No. 1
description:
In Pit Fighter: Fantasy Arena - Scenario Pack No. 1, a scenario pack for Pit Fighter: Fantasy Arena, you'll find four scenarios usable with the core rules and components found in the basic game and available expansions. Everything you need to play each scenario is included. Each scenario uses all of the core game rules unless exceptions and additions are noted in the rules that follow.

The scenarios included in Pit Fighter: Fantasy Arena - Scenario Pack No. 1 are:


Watch Your Back, Steven Ellis
Treasure in the Middle, Grey Endres
The Stable, Nelson Beach
Where Did He Go?, Nelson Beach
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures

name: Loom
description:
An abstract game where the players place markers on a chess board in sequence, where they can only place makers that are horizontally or vertically in line with their existing marker(s) without interrupt by other markers, and not placed such that they are on any line between a pair of existing markers of the same color. Players are trying to form a box of their colour, or if they can't, have the longest lines of their color.

Full rules at: http://www.luchacabra.com/?p=57

name: Kaiju Grand Prix
description:
You're racing giant monsters after a little rabbit -- first to catch the rabbit wins. Of course, you're a giant monster -- you can attack the other giant monsters, too. Each monster has custom abilities, and a variable number of actions depending on its "heart rate", which starts at 1, and goes up as things happen. You select as many dice as you have heart rate for different categories like attack, defense, or movement (simultaneously) then roll and evaluate. So, the higher the heart rate, the better -- except if your heart rate exceeds 10, you explode and lose the race.

Full rules at: http://www.luchacabra.com/?p=26
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Pomota
description:
Pomota -- for POstMOdern TActics is an abstract set of miniatures-like rules, using a chessboard as the playing field and (usually, though not required) chess pieces as the miniatures. It provides a set of rules for movement, combat, knock-out and elimination, and a points system for both evaluating wins and using the variable and specialized powers of the pieces.

Two possible "armies" are supplied, but it is clear that the idea is that this could be quite extensible.

Full rules at: http://www.luchacabra.com/?p=33

name: Coatl
description: Coatl is a race to get your pawns to the center of a spiral before your opponent(s), by rolling better. But, there are a couple twists -- the simple one is that landing on an opponent captures it, sending it back to the start. But, landing on your own piece allows you to combine them at which point they get enhanced powers, with a choice of what power to take. This combination is where the strategy comes in.

name: Archaeologists
description: Players are rival Archaeologists at the turn of the century. Players accumulate cards from one deck that allows them to draw cards from a second deck that earns them Victory Points. Lots of good card flavor.

name: Mystery Board
description:
"Watch the mystery ball magically select the correct answer. Over 100 questions on history, sports, science, entertainment and the world around us. Scoring board for competition play."

A two-player trivia game in which the object is to be the first player to answer ten questions correctly.

The game consists of a plastic board with an oval area to place the question/answer sheets and two scoring boards which are used to track how many correct answers each player has given.

The "mystery ball" is clear plastic dome mounted on a black base. At the edge of the base is a round hole or window which allows one to look through the base and onto the question/answer sheet. The mystery ball is placed on the question side of the board and turned to reveal one of the eight questions through the window in the base. The player then chooses an answer from among the eight answers. The mystery ball is then moved to the answer side of the board and it automatically (and mysteriously) turns to reveal the correct answer through the window in the base.

The question/answer sheets are double sided, providing eight questions in various categories, such as Space and Space Travel, Popular Music, Movies, Science and Inventors, Astrological Pairs, The World's Mostest, Where in the World, General Knowledge, Facts on Wheels, The Arts, Sports, History, Geography, Legends and Myths, and Who Is.

Publication date is approximate.

name: Chessling
description:
from Game Cabinet rules:

Use the same board and pieces as for International Chess (also known as English Chess or Western Chess).
Start with an empty board.

One side starts first on any square, after which play continues in turn. A player cannot pass his turn.

A legal move consists of one of the following:

placing one's own piece on an unoccupied square. The color of the square is immaterial.
moving a piece as per the International Chess rules with the exception of pawns. A pawn piece moves and captures like a King piece, that is one step in any direction. No promotion when a pawn reaches an edge of the board.
capturing an opponent's piece by moving one's own piece to that square.
The side who first captures all the opponent's pieces wins the game. If neither side can capture all the other side's pieces, and both sides agree to a draw then it is a draw.

Other possible variations: The size of the board, the number or types of pieces can be different from the International Chess set. To play handicap games, players can take unequal number of pieces or can start with initial placement of pieces such as pawns.

name: Shambattle: A Game for Old Fashioned Toy Soldiers
description: Shambattle is a old fashioned toy soldier battle game. It is the first miniature game published in the United States. It is played on hand drawn maps with toy soldiers and is intended to be played by children.

name: Lode Runner
description:
Lode Runner is based on the old Broderbund Software computer game of the same name (Lode Runner (1983)), and was in fact designed by a Broderbund employee.

The game contains eight different game boards of varying difficulty level - one of these is used for 2-4 players and two are recommended for 5-6 players, although the rulebook also shows configurations of four boards. ​Each player controls a runner and a guard and tries to have their runner collect as much gold as possible while eluding the other players' guards. Runners can dig much as in the computer game using hole tiles; players start with a few tiles and acquire more when they pick up gold. Guards attack other players' runners.

Once all gold has been collected the runners escape from the top of the playing area, with additional gold awarded to the first three to exit.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Movement Points, Square Grid

name: Nyomozz velünk!
description: This game is a Hungarian variant of Clue.
mechanics: Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Lokalspelet, Kampen om stan: Tvåstad
description:
This is yet another Monopoly clone. The publisher Lokaletspelet I Skandinavien AB did a lot of this games as promotions for different cities in the 1980s.

In the middle of the board are two photos of the cities; Tvåstad (Vänersborg and Trollhättan) and around them is a lot of the stores in those two cities. You can buy stock in them, and you can get cards that ask you questions about the city.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Elder Things & Outer Gods
description:
During the 2 billion year time period before the evolution of man, many different alien species, races, and entities have made Earth their home. Of these, there are six groups who stand out as being the most numerous and most powerful. These groups of colonizers include:
1. The Elder Things
2. Cthulhu and his Spawn
3. The Flying Polyps
4. The Great Race of Yith
5. Mi-go, the Fungi from Yuggoth
6. The Serpent People
All of these races fought each other for dominance on the planet. Often they would summon beings from other places, times, and dimensions to help them fight their Wars.
Elder Things and Outer Gods is a card and dice game where the various races (players) try to eliminate each other from existence. A free copy of the rules is available at:
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/ETOG.html

name: Up a Gum Tree
description:
Up A Gum Tree - A game for monkeys!
Throw the dice and move your monkey up the tree. Make use of the creepers, but watch out for the snakes! First to get their monkeys to the top wins the game.

This game is essentially a 3D 'Snakes and Ladders' with a number of subtle changes; each player has two monkeys, both of which must reach the top of the tree to win, each player's section of the tree has two creepers (which are the 'ladders'), but most importantly the pair of snakes on your section of the tree can be moved! Each player races his own pair of monkeys up the tree whilst attempting to avoid the two patrolling snakes, should a monkey and a snake end up on the same space, the monkey falls and has to start the climb over again. On your turn you can roll the dice and either move one of your own monkeys, or any snake (either to clear a route for your own monkeys or attempt to knock an opponents monkey back to the start).

name: The Sky's The Limit
description: Based on a local New York City children's game show, hosted first by Gene Rayburn and later Monty Hall, players try to complete a series of 49 stunts. The first team to compile a score of 1,000 points wins.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Square Play
description:
Square Play is an abstract strategy game played on a board of inset squares. Each player takes turns placing one of seven tokens in the hope of creating a square with four tokens. If they fail in that effort, players take turns moving a token to create either a square with four tokens or a straight line with three, whereupon they can remove an opponent's token.

Play continues until either a square is formed or until a player is eliminated due to having only 2 tokens left on the board.

name: Bowling Monkees
description: Monkey Bowling comes with 6 3" brightly painted wooden monkeys and 1 wooden ball. A fun game for children (and adults!) Play is just what you would expect - Set 'em up, knock 'em down!

name: Auctioneer
description: The object of this card game is to collect as many pairs as possible. The game, first published in 1916, has cards with objects on them, a gavel, and some coins. At the start of the game the cards are dealt and the coins distributed evenly. One player takes the first turn at being auctioneer. He takes up the gavel and declares an item for sale from his cards. The trick is the auctioneer can only describe the item by it's number of legs. Many different items have the same number of legs, so players have to bid on the chance that they are getting the item they need, without really knowing it. The purchaser of the card becomes the new auctioneer. As players earn pairs they set them aside and are assigned a value. When all cards are exhausted the winner is the one with the most value in pairs and in coins.

name: Fantasy & Science Fiction Movie Trivia Game
description:
From the box:

If you love the worlds of Hobbits, Wizards or starships this is the game for you. Questions range from the early days of Dracula and Frankenstein through to Harry and Frodo.

Contains: 200 Trivia Cards, Score Pad and Instructions.

Ages 12 and up.
categories: Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Trivia

name: Strontium Dog: Hell Planet
description: Game originally published in the Starlord comic book, based on the Strontium Dog comic. Play bounty hunter Johnny Alpha, Bestiariz, Cy-Ko, or Sergeant Syn. The first one to capture five targets wins the game.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Science Fiction

name: DAF Transport Game
description:
In this game players act as delivery drivers for DAF trucks, driving them through Europe to where they're required. Sometimes, in addition to delivering the truck, there may be a cargo to deliver on the way. Each time a successful delivery is made, the player gets a Delivery Bill. The winner of the game is the first to get a complete set of Delivery Bills.

This is principally a roll and move game, but players can use the die roll to move 1, 2 or 3 trucks, as long as the total moves equals the number on the die.

Contents:
game board
die
24 card holders
18 truck cards
6 road blocks
36 route cards
36 cargo cards
6 service tickets
18 devlivery bills
rule book
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: DAF Divisional Parts Marketing Services Department

name: Dragon War: Kinetic Kardz Set
description:
This 9 card set adds game board cards that are randomly inserted into the board and flip and spin or catch players that encounter them. The Demon and Labyrinth cards are especially nasty.

Expansion to Dragon War
categories: Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Find the Chicks
description: Players move their mother hens around the barnyard, trying to gather their chicks. Mothers are connected to chicks by magnetic attraction (in the base of their pieces).

name: Hometown Trivia
description: In this trivia game featuring Oshkosh, WI, you move around a board featuring businesses from the city and answer questions relating to it. You need to visit the businesses (which are all real Oshkosh establishments) to collected Product & Service cards in order to win. It was developed in the 1980's by David A. Colbert.

name: Which Way, Please? A Map Reference Game
description:
Which Way, Please? is a map reference game for children Ages 4 and up. It is designed to teach small children about the concept of grid maps. It consists of six collecting boards divided into nine grid squares, and 54 picture cards that magnify the village images on the collecting squares. The picture cards have grid references on their backs.

There are three games that can be played. The Solo Game asks the child to go through the picture cards one by one and match the grid references to the correct square on the right collecting board. When all cards are placed, the child then turns the cards over to see if the pictures correspond to those on the boards.

The Lotto Game doles out the collecting boards to each child. Each child in turn takes a card and shows it to everyone. If a player recognizes it as one that belongs on their board, that child gets the card. The first one to fill up the board is the winner.

In the Skill Game, the boards are connected to create a large village. The cards are turned up one by one, and the first child to call out the correct grid reference wins the card. The child with the most cards is the winner.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Shooters! Alias: The Hole in the Wall Game
description:
Description on the rules sheet:

A set of six finished wooden "pieces", one die, a set of 500 cards with 2,500 throughly fascinating facts on everything from Wiley Women to Ornery Outlaws, a box of "ammo", and a playing board. All of the above are contained in a beautiful red box with the silver letters "SHOOTERS" on the front.

Be the first to get to the center of the badge and become "sheriff". After successfully shooting it out with any remaining gunslingers, the sheriff then becomes "Marshal" and winner of the game.

name: Fast 'n' Furious College Football
description:
Fast-Action Games created many "quick-play" sports simulations where the outcome of a contest could be decided with just one or two dice rolls. These games made it easy to play an entire series of games in a matter of just a few minutes.

This game covers college football. Teams from the past (major conferences, minor divisions, even club teams--all the way back to the 1860s) were extensively researched to create ratings for just about any team a person would wish to play. The game includes normalization factors so that a team from 1890 could effectively be pitted against a team from 1980.

Fast-Action Game Description
COLLEGE FAST ’N’ FURIOUS FOOTBALL
This unique game features top teams EVERY year since 1869; 20 of the TOP teams EVERY year since 1889 are included! Service teams of WW I & WW II along with the legendary Indian schools of Carlisle & Haskell are also included. Now you can determine each year's National Champion on the field of play!! And you can set up DREAM tournaments to determine the GREATEST college football team of all- time! Imagine 1945 Army vs 1971 Nebraska! or 1972 USC against 1987 Miami! Over 2,500 great teams are included!
Complete game costs only $15 postpaid

name: Bingorello
description:
Bingorello is a game for seniors (60+), but for their families as well. A game that consists of 90 cards with 5 different flowers and a number. By rolling a die (NOT included in the game), it is decided which cards can be given to your opponent or turned around. First player to lose all his/her cards wins.

Released: Essen 2007.

name: Arctica
description:
Arctica is a children's game for different ages. The game is about building an igloo by recognizing form and color. Whoever builds his/her igloo first, wins. Different variants make that different ages can enjoy this game. It can be played with teams or 1 on 1.

Ages 4 and up. Released: Essen 2007.

name: World Cup Tennis
description:
This is an action simulation of Tennis made along the same principles as the Test Match cricket game.

Model players are attached to a controllable stand that is used on a scale model tennis court to server and hit the ball between the players.

If a players owns two sets doubles tennis with 4 players can also be played.
publishers: Bluebird Toys, Crown & Andrews Ltd., Peter Pan Playthings

name: Build-a-Thomas Game
description:
Be the first player to collect all eight pieces and build Thomas to win!

Players spin the spinner, and collect the piece of Thomas indicated. You can then place the piece on the base, building up your Thomas. The first player to complete their Thomas wins.

Play can continue for a number of games. Players get one point for each piece collected and that becomes their score for the game. You can either play a fixed number of rounds, or see who reaches a set score first.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Puzzle, Trains

name: Cranium Grab & Go Super Sudoku
description:
From the publisher:

The game of sudoku with fun Cranium twists
Compact packaging makes it ideal for travel
Fun for kids -- and adults!
Play with traditional rules or wacky new ones
A fun, affordable gift for family and friends
Need a burst of outrageous fun? Get your hands on Grab & Go Super Sudoku!

Get to know sudoku by playing with fun animal stickers on a smaller grid, then graduate to traditional play on a larger, more challenging grid.

What's in the box? Super Sudoku includes 2 game booklets (with 60 sudoku animal and number challenges), fun animal clings, 2 dry-erase pens, and double-sided puzzle board.

name: Formes et couleurs
description: Formes et couleurs (french title) is a Winnie The Pooh themed game for children 3 and up. Each player takes a board with a drawn scene and tries to fill the colored shapes on it. To do so they roll one shape-die (and one color-die if they are older) and are allowed to place a piece of the matching shape (and color with the advanced rules). If they have no more matching shape on their board, they have to pass. It helps children learn shapes and colors.

name: Kwest: A Game of the Sea
description:
Game comes like most Geographia Games with a separate board and a somewhat tiny components box.

Components are 50 sailing cards (45 with a single and 5 with a double sailing symbol), 5 location cards, 15 treasure cards, two cardboard ships on wooden stands, a wooden dice cup containing a special dice.

After setting up your starting hand (15 cards with the possibility to replace from the stockpile) you draw a location card where to dig up a pirates treasure.
Sailing is done with the symbol cards, also depicted on the different sailing routes on the board.
You have to fiddle out the best and farthest calculated moves with your hand, double symbol cards allowing double moves.
In the storm reigned region in the middle of the board you have to use the special dice, depicting the standard card symbols (spade, heart, club and diamond) and 2 anchors.

If you reach your destination island you have to land on the shores, now rolling an anchor on the dice.

If you dare, you can try to plunder another island on your way back to homeport, but beware: Winner is the one returning home first with a treasure !

What adds additional spice is the possibility to capture the opponents ship and that the movement cards are randomly chosen after you emptied your starting hand, so no more calculating your route is possible.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Dragon War: Alien Invasion
description: This expansion to Dragon War collects all 105 Alien cards to abduct and hassle the players.
categories: Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Science Fiction
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Malaya '41: The Fall of Singapore
description:
This game covers the Malayan campaign from 8 Dec 41 to the fall of Singapore in Feb 1942.
The map covers the Malayan peninsula. There appears to be 8 turns in the game, of which 1 turn equals approximately 1 week. Units are of battalion/regiment size.

Published in Command Magazine Japan # 77 on 20 Oct 07.

name: Pandas' Party
description:
Unusual game from the Pepys Card Game Series.

It consists of 54 playing cards and two key cards.

The 54 cards can be laid out to complete a large puzzle picture containing 9 x 6 cards.

All cards are dealt out, the player with the letter card "F" begins play by laying out this card. Next player in line tries to add a fitting card to it and so on.

Winner is the player getting rid of all his cards first.
Other players receive penalty points for cards left in their hands.
After reaching a points limit agreed beforehand play ends.

You can see the wartime production by the grey and thick card quality and the not-so-glossy-graphics, but still top !

name: Buy! Buy! Buy!
description:
In Buy! Buy! Buy!, players navigate a maze of different coloured shapes. Special dice depicting the possible shapes determine which paths are available to the players. Each die result can be used any number of times per turn, so long as each move is legal. Along the way, tokens are collected and redeemed at stores for merchandise. The first player to collect one of each commodity and return to the start position wins.

The game is shipped in a cardboard tube, with the board printed on vinyl rolled inside.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Eurojuego de Salamanca
description:
Eurojuego de Salamanca is a Monopoly like game played in this Spanish city. Nevertheless, they have introduced some variants that gives the game a twist for the better, such as the special commodities to buy or services contracts.

The game was distributed with El Adelanto, a local newspaper.
publishers: (Self-Published), Caja Duero, Periódico El Adelanto de Salamanca

name: Shok & Awe
description:
This game is a simulation of the early air bombing campaign against Iraq. Completely card driven, players draw missions and attempt to make their primary and any secondary or tertiary targets as possible by rolling dice, which can be modified by aircraft type, experimental weapons and recon missions.

Each target has a Class and a Combat Rating of 2, 3, 4, or 5.. In order to successfully destroy a target, the player must match or beat the Combat Rating listed for that target using as many dice as they wish.

name: Snap-Jacks
description:
The board consists of a 4x4 square grid of scoring positions with a point value of either 5, 10, or 15. Each scoring position contains a 5x5 grid of holes. So the overall interior grid of holes is 20x20. Around the edges of the board are 23 additional single holes which are scattered sparsely, with values from 25 to 75.

Each player gets a seesaw-like device with a hole in one end for placing his or her jacks. Players then 'snap' the other end of the device to fling the jack into the air and (one hopes) into a hole on the board. Jacks that do land in holes on the board score based on where they land.
publishers: Saml. Gabriel Sons and Company, Schylling

name: Mad Lab Monster Surgery
description:
Product Features:

+ 3 games in 1 scary head!

+ Grave Emergency, Scary Surgery and Creepy Check-Up games will leave you in stitches!

+ Scary monster phrases and sounds plus removeable head parts

+ Colours and style may vary

+ Requires 3 x AA batteries (not included)

+ Manufacturer's recommended age 5 years +

By Vivid Imaginations (in UK)
categories: Action / Dexterity, Electronic, Fantasy, Horror, Humor, Medical, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Alphabet Soundtracks
description: Take a gameboard for each player and put the counters in a pile where everyone can reach them. Start the tape at any point on either side. Listen carefully to the tongue twisters. When you hear a toungue twister that matches one of the pictures on your board, cover that picture with a counter. The winner is the first player to cover all their pictures with counters. For a more challenging game, turn the boards over and match the tongue twisters to the right letters.

name: Cop & Killer
description:
During the game, players take the role of bystanders, cops, and killers. These secret identities are revealed throughout the course of the game. Cops attempt to make an arrest. Killers attempt to kill their target. Bystanders can help influence the outcome one way or the other.

A more informative description: The game comes with a full set of english rules already and its game components are fully language independent.

Cop & Killer is an interactive game for up to 10 players, where the gameplay focuses on a Killer trying to kill his Target and the Cop tries to capture the Killer before he is on his victim. At the beginning each player randomly receives hidden an identity marker which identifies him either as the Cop, the Killer, the Target or a Bystander. These identity badges are kept by the players in their hands under the table, and before a game round starts the players can secretly exchange the badges on a one to one base so that nobody knows the true identity of the others. The ID badges come in different shapes to avoid looking at the badges while exchanging them, so that the players know which badge they are holding, so there is no need for them to look at them under the table.

When the badges have been assigned by the players, the meeple in form of a bullet is placed on the gameboard and playing commences. In turn, the players now roll a set of a red and a blue dice, and they may move the bullet clockwise around the board for a number of spaces corresponding to the number rolled with one of the dice. During the course of the game, the identities of the players may be revealed, and when this has happened to Cop, Killer or Target their rules for using the dice will be slightly changed. So, the Cop now must use only the blue dice and moves the bullet clockwise, but he may decide to move less spaces than rolled by the dice, to simulate the chosen path of investigation (coffee ? Yes or no?). The Killer on the other hand uses the red dice and must move the exact number of spaces, but he may chose to go clockwise or counter-clockwise. Finally, the Target may use the result of one or both dice and move the bullet clockwise around the board.

On the gameboard, the players will encounter a number of spaces which allow them to perform an action, but before describing those actions let me say a little bit more about the mechanics of the gameboard. So, each action space either has a blue or red background colour, depending on whether the action is beneficial for the Cop or the Killer. A player who lands on such a space and performs the action afterwards takes a coin of the corresponding colour, representing either a reward for helping the Police or a bribe for helping the Killer. When the round ends, either the Cop or the Killer will have been successful, earning the player of Cop or Killer one victory point. However, in addition the two players (Bystanders) who helped the successful Cop or Killer most and earned most coins of the winning colour also will be awarded one victory point, and then a new round of play will start until all 10 victory points of either Cop or Killer have been distributed.

At this place, it becomes important to notice that the gameboard is double sides and can be flipped from a side depicting the Cop's office to the Crime Scene and backwards. The side with the Cop's office shows more actions which are beneficial for the Cop and the players who have chosen to assist him, whereas the side of the Crime Scene features more red actions which can be used by the Killer and his henchmen. The change of both sides of the gameboard is triggered by one space on each side, featuring either a car key or an office key, and the player who move the bullet onto the corresponding space flips the gameboard over and receives a correspondingly coloured coin.

The action blue spaces which are favourable for the Cop and his assisting players are the following:

* Circumstancial Evidence: the active player may chose any other player- That player must reveal his identity.
* Successful Investigation: The Cop has finished his investigations. All identity markers are uncovered.
* Interrogation: The active player may chose another player and ask him a direct question which must be answered truthfully by "yes" or "no". It may be asked whether the questioned player has a specific identity, and if this turns out to be true the player's identity must be revealed. However, the question may also be of a more indirect nature, only asking whether a player would try to assist the Killer during his next turn etc. In this case, no identity marker will be revealed, but the questioned player is bound to his answer on his following turn.

On the other hand, the following red spaces are more useful for the Killer:

* Informant: The active player may ask an other player whether he is the Target. If this is ture, the Traget must reveal his identity.
* Betrayal: The player entering this space must reveal his own identity.
* Target in sight: The Target must reveal its identity.

When Cop or Killer are revealed, they discard all coins they have collected during this round, since from now onwards they are pursuing their own aims which are not quite congruent with those of the Bystanders. However, until then they should collect coins and normal, and they possibly have the chance to put the other players onto a wrong track by the colour of coins they collect.

Finally, there are also a blue and a red action space which lead to the climate of the round: the blue Arrest space and the red Assault space. For an Arrest, the identities of Cop and Killer must be revealed, whereas an Assault needs Killer and Target to be revealed. If the Cop or the Killer decide to act, two dice are rolled, and if the acting player (Cop in case of Arrest, Killer in case of Assault) rolls a higher result on his dice than on the other dice, he may shoot that number of arrows with the included Dartgun at a target marker which has been set up at a chosen distance. If one of the darts hits, the round is over and the shooting player and his two best assistants will have won, but if no hit was scored the game continues. However, if the shooting was successful and if, after the distribution of victory points, all ten victory points of one colour have been used up, the game ends and the player with most victory points will have won.

Wow, this game plays astonishingly well, and the playing mechanism certainly is not just a vehicle which forms the background for some otherwise senseless dartgun shooting. Quite the opposite, the gameplay is quite multi-faceted and offers a good degree of playing depth which is somewhat counterbalanced by the interactive element of shooting. The guessing and deduction of the players starts at the end of a round when the identity markers have to be exchanged, since no player may keep the badge of Cop, Killer or Target for two consecutive rounds. Depending on the positioning of the players around the table, each player may make some first deductions on who might now have which identity badge. During the game itself, it will be especially the Bystanders who will try to spoil an early victory of Cop or Killer, since they first want to collect enough coins to participate in the distribution of victory points at the end of the round. So, it will always be a few players who want to move for ending the round, while the others want to postpone the inevitable end until the get into a better position themselves. For this reason, especially the Interrogation action is rather useful, since a player who is asked a question is bound to his answer on his following turn. This may lead to a considerable restriction of his actions, depending on the way a question is asked.

The extensive care which was put into this game is reflected by the artwork, the components (including a very robust and seemingly durable dartgun from a German manufacture) and the body of the rules. Special provisions for only four players for teamplay with 7 to 10 players are included, as well as a full English version of the rules. Even the details are harmonious, with a real-looking bullet as a playing piece and a carboard-piece resembling a yellow "Police Line" which is used to mark off the line after which the shooter must stand. To my mind, Cop & Killer is a really outstanding interactive group game, and with people who do not mind the somewhat violent topic really thrilling games should be possible.

Most of the text is originally written by kulkmanns gamebox as a review by Frank Schulte-Kulkmann on boardgame.de
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Secret Unit Deployment, Variable Player Powers

name: Craonne 1814
description:
Game published by the magazine "Le journal du Stratege" nº 60/61 spokesman of the Cercle de Strategie.
Map of 41 x 30 cm and 30 counters.
It reproduces the battle between Russians and French in the Campaign France of 1814 and was one of Napoleon's complete victories.

name: Superstars
description:
A trivia game where the game host (called the impresario in the game) role rotates between the players.
An impresario is first selected, and then picks a random picture from the deck of cards.
Within a time limit, the other players have to write down the name of the star/celebrity. Only those who have the right answer can then get an extra trivia question on that celebrity for extra points. The specific question is determined by a 12-sided roll.
All the wrong answers are giving points to the impresario.
Once the impresario has done 4 cards/photographs (and possibly 4 trivia questions), the player to the left becomes the impresario.

At the end of an agreed number of impresario rounds, the player with the most points win.

name: Animal Crackers Game
description:
