After the first preliminary visit to each state, the aspiring candidate must decide which States to pursue and which to leave for their opponent. Sometimes it will prove to be good strategy to play a weaker card and save the real muscle for other States!

After two trips around the country, the electoral votes are counted. Being American politics, only the slimmest of margins is necessary for victory in any given state. The candidate with the highest number of electoral college votes is the winner, and the next President of the United States.

How will you play your cards?

name: Kalle-spelet Jakten på knattarna
description:
Knatte, Fnatte and Tjatte won't do their homework, they want to go to the boathouse instead. Can you help them to reach the boathouse without getting caught by Donald Duck.

Contents:
1 board game
1 Donald Duck piece
12 wooden pieces 4x3
2 dice
rules

name: Tactique
description:
Tactique - A Battle Of Colors

Tactique is a quick strategy game suitable for both children and adults. Players randomly divide a set of 14 cards with varying numbers of red spots, yellow spots, and holes in a 3x3 grid, then alternate placing cards on the stack, scoring points for both players based on the number of spots showing in each color. Winner is the player with the most points at the end of the game.

name: Farm 3-D Memory Match-Up
description:
From the publisher:
Test your memory with this cute mix of fun farm animals! Split each animal top and bottom apart and hide each half under haystack cups, then mix them up and see if you can remember which is which! First person to match the most animals win!

Contents:
- 20 Farm Animal Game Parts (10 complete animals)
- 20 Haystack Cups
- 1 Egg Carton Storage Case

Box Size:
11.25" Length x 5.00" Width x 5.13"H / 1.5 lbs

name: Bimmelkette
description:
Bimmelkette
Bell-Ringing Chain (English translation)

By throwing dice players collect wooden beads and wooden animals as indicated on their task cards, comparing their colors and threading them on a colored shoestring with a bell tied in the middle.

The players try to complete their chain in the right order to match the picture by means of luck and manual dexterity.

Dice with colored circles are used to determine whether the player can thread a certain color or collect a bead or animal from the box, depending upon the variation played.

Three games variations are outlined: "grundspiel" or basic; "mischfarben" or blended colors; and "symmetrie" or symmetry.

The player who is first to right the bell of his/her completely threaded and correctly ordered chain is the winner.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Dice, Puzzle
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: Piratspelet
description:
A game similar to (but not identical to) Ludo, where the players race to be first to the treasure in the middle of the board.

2-4 players can play, taking turns. Each have three pieces, moving by rolls of a die along interconnected paths that lead to the treasure. The paths are organized in three distinctive levels with paths between them. The players can knock out other player's pieces by landing on them so they start over (just like in Ludo). The paths include special spots, including green spots (skip three turns), red spots (slide down to an earlier path, like in Snakes&Ladders) and blue spots (entrance to the next level).

It is clearly of german origin since it is designed by Rolf Kauka, a famous german cartoonist. German publications and name are unknown. A swedish low-cost version was sold in Sweden in the 1970's, most likely produced by Klee. Although Klee is not printed on the game, Klee made other games in identical boxes with similar part numbers.

The game is mostly known in Sweden through a famous comedy sketch from the late 60's, with four adults trying to socialize by playing the game but the play quickly turns into bickering. This makes the game particularly interesting as a game that everybody knows about but few have played.

Contents:
1 Boardgame
12 playing pieces 4x3
1 dice
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Napoleon 1796-1800
description:
Strategic-operational scale wargame about Italian campaigns of Bonaparte in 1796-1800.

Game scale:
1 counter = army/corps/division or commander
1 turn = 2 days

name: Monopoly: Hildesheim
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Hildesheim, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Lübeck
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Lübeck, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Mainz
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Mainz, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

description:

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Mönchengladbach, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Würzburg, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: MARE NOSTRVM
description: Mare Nostrum (MARE NOSTRVM) is a Brazilian game simulating the battles that were fought among Roman and Greek galleys. There is no map. You can play it on the table or floor.

name: Silver Isle
description:
Each player represents a nation of Europe seeking wealth from a newly discovered island during the age of colonial expansion: England, Pirate Confederation, Spain or France. After forming the isle, players move colonist crews (coins) across the isle on foot, or around the coast by sea in a ship (pawn). Crews exploring new land on foot claim new property for their port (null tile), may establish a mine (die), and fight enemy colonists. After a mine is established, crews may mine the site and transport silver (tokens) to their colony or their ship. The ship may transport silver and/or crews around the coast of the isle and to Europe (off board).

Silver Isle is played with a Piecepack set and the rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

Piecepack Game System
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Secret Unit Deployment

name: MotoX
description:
Pronounced "motocross", this is, as you might expect, a game of racing motorbikes. Using a Piecepack set, the players create a three-dimensional race track with "jump ramps" created by piling coins under tiles in the track. Players roll dice to determine how far they move, but the farther back in the pack you are the more dice you roll. Also unused coins can be used to add more dice to your roll for a turn, or to recover from a wipe-out.

Rules are available on the Piecepack Wiki

Game System

Piecepack Game System

name: King's Progress
description:
Medieval Kings would often visit the various cities of their kingdoms in order to enforce tax collection and discourage thoughts of rebellion and treason. This was known as a Progress. In this game each player acts as a King’s chancellor
overseeing the King’s Progress throughout the cities of the kingdom. The aim is to collect the most tax at the end of the game by steering your own King through the richest cities with the highest investments while scheming to force the Kings of your opponents to travel through poor cities with low investments.

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

Piecepack Game System

name: Släpp fram mig!!
description:
This is a childrens game. Your job is to get both your boat and your car to the finish-line before your opponent does. Will the bridge be open for your boat or the car? Happy racing.

Contents:
1 board game
2 bridges
1 usual dice
1 symbolic dice
8 playing pieces
4 tull marker
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Anera's Arena uitbreiding #1
description:
This expansion for Anera's Arena adds ranged attacks and magic to the game.

Two new attributes are added to the characters:
- Magic Points, that together with Movement Points may be used to cast spells
- Magic Resistance, that measures the chance a character can resist a spell.

Four new characters are added to the game:

The Elf - Armed with a bow, the Elf attack up to four spaces away. He has a spell that allows him to shoot faster.

The Halfling - The Halfling can throw stones (up to two squares). A hit will cause the opponent to fall.

The Orc - When the Orc hits with an attack, he may make a second attack.

The Mage - The Mage has several spells available in the game: A Fireball and a Stab of Pain to damage an opponent, Heal/Repair to heal someone or repair armor, Forced Movement to move an opponent and Double Pillar to double the movement speed of a pillar.

Expands:

Anera's Arena

name: AFV
description:
“A two-player card game of modern tank combat. Each player starts the game with 16 AFV (Armored Fighting Vehicle) Tokens. Reduce your opponent to 0 AFV tokens.”

Each player starts with a hand of ten cards drawn from a common deck. The card types include Offensive Attack, Defensive Attack, Units, Weapons, Movement, Obstacle, Protection, Leadership, Morale, and Reconnaissance. Each turn has 8 phases: Deploy Phase, Leadership Phase, Reconnaissance Phase, Defensive Phase, Defensive Movement Phase, Offensive Phase, Offensive Movement Phase, and Redeploy Phase.

In order to win the game, a player must play cards to mount successful attacks which result in the opponent's loss of AFV tokens.

name: AFV Skirmish
description:
“Two Player Board & Card Game of Modern Tank Combat. Victory: Destroy all enemy Armored Fighting Vehicle Units. Units: Each player starts the game with 8 AFV (Armored Fighting Vehicle) Units. Use Miniatures, counters, or tokens to represent AFV’s. Each Unit represents a combined arms squadron.”

The play of the cards is central to the game, as the cards control when the AFV's can move, attack, and defend.

name: Agea
description:
“Greek Heroes undertake adventures of Mythic proportions. Players accumulate Heroes, City States, Relics, and great Victories over legendary monsters with the aid of the Gods. To play you will have to make your own cards. There are 129 cards in the deck.”

The object of the game is to accumulate the most Victory Points. Victory Points are acquired by controlling Heroes and City States, owning Relics, winning Wars, holding Blessing cards, and successfully completing Challenges.

name: Air Fare
description:
A bidding card game in which the players control airlines. The object is to have the most money at the end of the game.

The game is played using a custom deck consisting of 110 cards of three different types: Planes, Landing Rights, and Events. Landing Rights cards are also called Terminals. Also required for play are a ten-sided die and a paper and pen to record profits (or play money may be used to represent profits instead).

Each player starts the game with 50 million dollars, one Boeing 737 or one McDonnell Douglas DC-9, and landing rights to two Minor Airports. The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck.

name: Air Tac
description:
A game of modern jet fighter dogfighting for two players. Each player starts with two jets: a leader and a wingman. You win the game by shooting your opponent’s planes out of the air.

The game uses a custom deck of over 150 cards which regulate movement and combat. The game may be played on a chess board or any other 8x8 grid. Also required for play are six-sided dice, miniature airplanes that fit within the squares of the board, and counters to keep track of missiles and damage.

name: Air to Air
description:
“Two player card game simulating modern Jet Fighter Air Combat. Objective: Kill all of your opponent’s planes. Setup: In the standard game each side has 2 planes: A flight leader and his wingman. For a quick game play one-on-one. A dogfight involving many planes is referred to as a Furball. Use coins or dice to keep track of planes.”

The game is played using a deck of seven different types of cards: Pilot, Initiative, Tactics (Team), Maneuver, Attack, Defense, and Kill. The players attempt to play a superior number of Maneuver and Attack cards, and ultimately score a kill with a Kill card.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Modern Warfare

name: Alien Empires
description:
Alien races with varying powers compete to control twenty worlds. The Alien Race which establishes control over all of the Worlds wins the game.

The card deck used in the game includes three types of cards: Force cards, Race cards, and Event cards. Each player also requires a uniquely colored set of fifty or more Control markers. The game may be played on any hex map with the twenty World markers distributed as the players see fit.

Your quest for galactic conquest starts from the home world of your choice. In addition, you begin the game with three Race cards that define abilities, traits and powers that your alien race will possess throughout the game.

name: Aliens
description:
A card game pitting one player’s Colonial Marines versus the other player’s Aliens.

Each player has a deck of 36 cards equally divided into three suits (Combatants, Weapons, and Tactics). Players attempt to build hands with the greatest combat value. When battles are lost, the cards are discarded to a Casualty Pile.

The game ends when all of a player’s cards are in the Casualty Pile, at which point the other player wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: American Revolution
description:
“Two player Card game of the American Revolution. One player is the Americans, the other is the British."

"Players share a common deck. The card list has 120+ cards."

"The game is played in 7 Strategic turns corresponding to the 7 years of the war: 1775, 1776, 1777, 1778, 1779, 1780, 1781."

"Victory: The winner is the first player to win 3 turns in a row, or if this does not occur, the player to win turn 1781. (It’s not how many battles you won, it’s who won the last battle.)”
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Card Game, Print & Play

name: Ancient Battlefields
description:
“Ancients Wargame with emphasis on Command & Control. Victory: You win if you rout the opposing General.”

Played on a square grid with terrain arranged as desired by the players. The game includes a detailed scenario generation system which allows for randomly determined army quality and composition, and leaders of varying ability (including attributes for “legendary generals.”) The rules also describe special characteristics and/or special units for the Egyptians, Mongols, Greeks, Athenians, Spartans, Persians, Romans, Carthaginians, and Celts.

name: Archmagi
description:
A strategic scale fantasy wargame depicting the struggle between Mages (Archmagi), who use spells, heroes, monsters, armies, and artifacts to destroy each other and conquer the world.

The game is played on a hex map randomly created during the course of the game, or created using an online random map generator. The players start at the opposite ends of the mapsheet with their randomly selected Archmagi, and a small assortment of units and spells. The goal is to destroy all opposing Archmagi units.

At start, all non-player Archmagi chits, Spell chits, Banner chits, Artifact chits, and Unit chits are set aside to be recruited by the players in the course of the game. Units may only be recruited from the territory in which they originate, e.g. Dwarves in the mountains, Elves in the forest, Trolls in the swamp, etc. The players obtain Artifacts (magic weapons/items) by turning in two reserve Units. Each player receives three randomly selected spells every turn, but a player may only hold a total of seven spells at a time.

name: Archon Skirmish
description:
A game based on the classic action-strategy computer game of the same name. The game is played on an 8×8 grid (such as a chess board.) Victory is achieved by occupying all four corner squares or by eliminating all enemy creatures.

Each player has a unique set of eight fighting creatures, all of which are rated for hits, movement, and attack. The Light forces consist of the Wizard, Unicorn, Archer, Golem, Valkyrie, Djinni, Phoenix, and Knight. The Dark forces are the Sorceress, Basilisk, Manticore, Troll, Shapeshifter, Dragon, Banshee, and Goblin.

Card play is central to the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and the cards permit units to move, attack, and cast spells.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Print & Play

name: Aztec Skirmish
description:
“Battle between Aztecs & Conquistadors. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill the opposing Leader.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters may be used to represent the combatants. The Aztec force consists of a War Leader, two Jaguar Knights, two Eagle Knights, and 19 Warriors. The Conquistador force consists of a Captain, two Cannons, four Horsemen, and eight Soldiers. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

name: Big Trouble in Little China:  Skirmish
description:
A board game based on the John Carpenter film Big Trouble in Little China.

“One player controls Egg Shen and his Allies. The other player controls Lo Pan & his Minions. Each figure represents one Man (Unit). Abstract simulation of the Battle at the end of the Movie. Victory: The Egg Shen player wins if he kills Lo Pan. Lo Pan wins if he kills Egg Shen, Jack Burton, and Wang Chi.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Egg Shen is teamed up with Jack Burton, Wang Chi, and six Chang Sing Fighters. Assisting Lo Pan are the Three Storms (Lightning, Rain, and Thunder), the Chinese Ogre, and eight Wing Kong Fighters.

The players draw hands of cards from a custom deck of 44 cards. Card play determines when units may move or attack.
categories: Fighting, Horror, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Buck Rogers
description:
“Welcome to the World of the 25th Century. Help Buck defeat the Han Empire! The Decks: One player gets the Org Deck. The other player gets the Han Deck. Victory: The first player to win 5 hands is the winner.”

Each hand the players fill their hands to seven cards (Arrival Phase), can discard and redraw up to four (Reinforcements Phase), and then the players reveal some, none or all of their cards (Adventure Phase). Each player adds up the Force values of their cards, the player with the higher total wins the hand (Cliffhanger Phase.) The winner of the hand then makes an improvisational narrative of the Episode reflected by the turn using some or all of the cards played as a basis (Narrator Phase.)
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Science Fiction

name: Cards of Mars
description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Theme is the John Carter of Mars series by Edgar Rice Burroughs. Victory: The first player to accumulate 75 Victory Points (VP) wins. The Deck: Players share a common deck. There are several card types: Heroes, Villains, Beasts, Enemies, Weapons, Plots, Events. All cards fall into one of two categories: Friend cards or Foe cards. All cards have a numerical 'Force' value.”

The players attempt to form eight card melds consisting of at least one Hero or Heroine “Friend Card”, one Plot “Foe Card”, and at least one Enemy or Villain “Foe Card.” Because the good guys always win, the total Force value of the Friends Cards must equal or exceed the Force value of the Foe Cards. The player scores Victory Points equal to the Force value of the Foe Cards played in the meld.

name: Death in the Sand
description:
“Morocco circa 1925. Berber Tribesmen attack a company of French Foreign Legionnaires. Each player has a unique deck. Victory: The first player to win 4 hands wins the battle.”

Using eight card hands, the players each simultaneously play melds of Leader, Men, Terrain, Weapon, Morale and Tactics Cards. The player who plays the meld with the higher total Force Value wins the hand.

name: Dueling Pistols
description:
“Simulation of a Pistol Duel circa 1700+. Duelists agree to one of the following: One Shot, Multiple Shots (2,3,or 4), First Blood, Death. They may also forgo the Speed element of the Duel and allow the Challenged to fire first.”

The custom deck is divided into four suits: Speed, Aim, Range, and Hit. The Speed cards determine who fires first. Your Aim cards must total higher than your opponent’s Range cards to score a hit. The total of your Hit cards, when compared to those of your opponent, determine whether a player who was hit is wounded or killed.

Your success in the duel falls into one of four categories: “You are Killed: Major Defeat. You are Wounded: Minor Defeat. Opponent Wounded: Minor Victory. Opponent Killed: Major Victory.”

name: Go Joe
description:
“G.I. Joe vs Cobra. 2 player game: Board, Cards, Dice. There are 2 decks. One player gets the Joe Deck. The other player gets the Cobra Deck. Victory: You win if you ever capture your opponent’s base, or you control all ‘Urban’ spaces on the board.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid with spaces large enough to hold a card. The G.I. Joe base is in one corner of the board and the Cobra base is in the opposite corner. The remaining 62 spaces are a random mix of eight terrain types: Jungle, Swamp, Sea, Desert, Mountain, Forest, Urban, and Arctic.

Each player starts with four Teams and a hand of cards. Each card has the name and statistics for a soldier. The cards are placed under each Team counter to represent the soldiers in that Team.

Teams engage in combat by moving into the same space as an opposing Team. Combat is resolved based on one of three unit factors (as determined randomly by a die roll): Firepower, Close Combat, or Tactics. Combat bonuses are given for various factors, including having a team with soldiers from the same service branch or when units are defending their base. Combat resolution also takes into consideration artillery units, armor units vs. anti-armor, and air units vs. “anti-air.”
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Open Drafting

name: Guild Master
description:
“Players take the role of founding fathers of a medieval town. The best builder earns the title of Guild Master.”

The game is played with a custom deck of 116 cards. Each card specifies a type of Location and the Resources it provides. Some cards also specify additional Resources that are provided when they are combined with other specific Location cards.

Players obtain cards by drawing them from the deck and trading. On each turn, a player declares which type of Resource category to build, and then plays any cards of that category.

The game ends at the end of the turn that the last card is drawn from the deck. The winner is the player whose town provides the highest scores in the most number of Resource categories.

name: Grail
description:
“Fantasy Card game. 2-6 players. Players take the role of Arthurian Knights on the quest for the Holy Grail. Object: The first player to accumulate 7 'Quest' tokens is the winner.”

“Materials: There are 65 cards in the deck. Players will have to create their own cards in order to play. A six sided die is required to play. 7 'quest tokens' per player are needed.”

Each player’s turn consists of two to four phases. In the Draw Phase, two cards a drawn. This is followed by the Fate phase, in which the player decides whether or not to quest for the grail. If the player declines to quest, the turn ends.

If a player decides to quest, the Adventure Phase comes next. The opponent to the left of the phasing player may play a Test Card. If the phasing player is able to pass the Test, then the other opponents may continue to play Test Cards against the phasing player. This continues until no opponents offer a Test Card. If any Test is failed, the turn ends. If all Tests are met, then the Quest Phase follows. Quests are resolved based on a die roll combined with Aid cards played by the phasing player.

“If you accumulate 7 Quest tokens, than you are deemed worthy to receive the Holy Grail, and you win.”
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Mythology

name: Galactic Supremacy
description:
“You guessed it. Rival space empires are at it again. A card game for 2 or more players.” The object of the game is to capture the Homeworlds of all your opponents. The game is played with a custom deck of 75 cards.

The players earn Credits by controlling Sectors of space. Credits may be used to open new Sectors and to put Fleets and Leaders into play. Credits may also be used to research one of the nine types of technology. The level of technological development plays into the combat system, which is the means by which enemy fleets and sectors are destroyed and Homeworlds are captured.

name: Fusillade
description: “Two-player card game of Napoleonic Warfare. Players share a common deck. The deck contains three types of cards: Unit, Tactics, and Strategy. Each player starts with 100 points of troops. Use change to keep track of troop points. Victory: Reduce your opponent’s troop total to zero.” Troop casualties are inflicted by successfully playing cards during the Attack Phase.

name: Formula Ace Racing Pods
description:
“This game is a futuristic race of the WipeOut or Star Wars episode 1 kind.”

“A single championship is made of one or several circuits. Except if otherwise voted by all players, all circuit will have to be played three time, once for each category. Each race belongs to one special category and has special rules and only the third one allows the use of weapons. Categories are: Total Speed Way - a speed race where the initial risks bidding is essential, Dragster Show - an die-fast competition where wreckage are far from being uncommon, Destruction Derby - where the pilots are allowed weapons aboard.”

There are four different kinds of racing ships, each rated for Speed, Hit Points, and “Space Available” for further customization. Pilots are rated for Piloting and G-Endurance.

name: Fleets of the Imperium
description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Space Combat in the Games Workshop Warhammer 40K Space Fleet Universe. Pick your Fleet: Tyranid, Imperial, Eldar, or Necron. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Flagship.”

The game is played on a chessboard or other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each player has a fleet of sixteen ships comprised of one flagship and four other types of ships, which vary depending on the type of fleet chosen. Each ship is rated for hits, movement, and size.

Each type of fleet uses a custom deck of cards which is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from their decks. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

name: Fix Bayonets
description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. WWI Theme. Abstract skirmish level combat. Man to Man fighting in the Argonne Forest 1918. One player is the defending American Lost Battalion. The other player is the attacking German Stormtroopers. Victory: You win if you kill both of your opponents Officers.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each player starts with the following assortment of sixteen units: two Officers, ten Riflemen, two Heavy Weapon Specialists, one Runner, and one Sniper.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move and attack. Terrain cards may be used to defeat attack or movement cards.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play, World War I

name: Devastators 3000
description:
“The high tech version of Devastators 2500. The larger Interstellar warships go by many categorical names:
Dreadnaughts, Battlers, Star Cruisers, and of course, Devastators. Each player controls a Devastator, or ship, represented by his deck. Play pits Devastator vs Devastator. Run out your opponent’s deck to destroy his ship.”

The game uses a custom deck with over 100 cards. The object of the game is to destroy the opposing Devastator. The ships can move between short, medium, and long range. Attack cards may be played at the appropriate range. Devastators may also launch Fighter Squads or Nanotech Swarms which continue to fight the opposing ship until they are destroyed.

When you inflict damage on an opposing ship, your opponent must discard a number of cards equal to the damage inflicted. When all of your opponent’s cards are in his Destroyed discard pile, you have eliminated him from the game.

name: Devastators 2500
description:
“The larger Interstellar warships go by many categorical names: Dreadnaughts, Battlers, Star Cruisers, and of course, Devastators. Each player controls a Devastator, or ship, represented by his deck. Play pits Devastator vs Devastator. Run out your opponents deck to destroy his ship.”

The game uses a custom deck of cards. The object of the game is to destroy the opposing Devastator. When you damage the opposing ship, your opponent must discard a number of cards equal to the damage inflicted. When all of your opponent’s cards are in his Destroyed pile, you have won the game.

Re-implemented by:
Devastators 3000

name: Battle of New Orleans
description:
“The British with superior numbers charge into a shower of cannon shot and sniper fire while attempting to install Ladders over the Rodriguez canal. Their goal is to overrun the American defenders, however their leadership and troop Strength is being decimated. Can the British complete the task before it is too late? Victory: The Americans win if all British units are destroyed. The British win if all American units are overrun. Otherwise the British score is the number of American units that were overrun. The British player with the highest score wins.”

In this abstract wargame, set during the War of 1812, the British units are represented by six-sided dice. The face-up number shows the strength of each unit. The units are moved down a twenty space track. Moving dice off the end of the track helps reduce the strength of the American forces by removing cards from the American Troop deck. The British win when all American Troop cards have been eliminated.

The game may be played in three different ways: solitaire, two-player (American versus British), or multiplayer (two or more players play the British competing for high score).

name: Bujutso
description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Oriental Martial Arts Theme. Abstract skirmish level combat. Man to Man fighting. Victory: You win if you kill your opponents Leader.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the men, which come in three types: Leaders, Bodyguards, and Followers. The players also choose they type of Warrior Band they are playing: Samurai, Ninja, Monk or Bushi.

Each type of Warrior Band uses a custom deck of cards which is central to the play of the game. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

name: Castle Siege
description: The Defenders have sixteen units: four Knights, four Archers, four Cannons, and four Boiling Oil Cauldrons. The Attackers are assaulting with twenty-eight units: eight Knights, four Archers, four Cannons, four Sappers, four Battering Rams, and four Siege Towers. The Attackers must breach the castle walls to take the fight to the Defenders. A six-sided die is used to resolve combat, and to determine how many units a player may move.

name: Cat & Mouse
description:
“Two player card game representing terrorist activity and government countermeasures. One player represents US Security. The other player is the Terrorists.”

Each player uses a unique deck of cards. The U.S. player attempts to play combos which force the Terrorist player to discard cards. The Terrorist player is attempting to play a meld, which represents a successful attack and ends the game. The U.S. player wins if the Terrorist player runs out of cards without playing a meld. The U.S. player can also win by guessing the Terrorist player’s meld as it is played but before the cards are revealed, which represents the attack being preempted.
categories: Card Game, Modern Warfare, Print & Play

name: Cellular
description:
“Card game using concepts from general biology. The deck includes 85 cards. Object: Accumulate the most points at the end of the game, or over several games.”

Each player is dealt a hand of eight cards from which they attempt to play special combinations. Over forty combinations are defined, such as Photosynthesis (using the cards Chloroplast, Chlorophyll, Light Reactions, Dark Reactions), Sexual Reproduction (using Gametes, Fertilization, Zygote), and Mitosis (with Mitosis, Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase, Telophase.)

One point is scored for each card in the combination. The game ends once there are no cards left in the deck or any time a player has no cards left in his hand.

name: Champion Chess
description:
A two player card game with a chess theme. One player plays Black, the other plays White. Each player has an identical custom deck of 52 cards, composed of Noble cards and Aid cards. The object of the game is to capture your opponent’s King.

The game consists of a series of challenges, where the player’s simultaneously choose one Noble card from their hands and lay it face up on the table. The players can then add up to six Aid cards from their hands, played face down, to assist the Noble. All cards are then turned face up to see which side has the highest combined Move, Attack, and/or Defend ratings. The losing Noble is captured. In the case of a tie, both Nobles are captured.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Open Drafting, Secret Unit Deployment, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Colonial Florida
description:
“Historical period: Florida 1513 (Ponce de Leon) – 1821 (American posession). Each player represents one colonial power: Spanish, British, or French. The Deck: Players share the Enhancement deck. The deck contains two types of cards: Income Cards & Combatants.”

These cards are played onto an abstract map of Florida, a ring of 36 spaces marked with the names of geographic features and locations of settlements. The players gain income by controlling settlements.

The first player to accumulate 50 Gold is the winner.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Colonials
description: “Each player controls a coastal colonial settlement in 17-18th Century North America. Each player’s colony is from an opposing European group including: The English, French, Spanish, and Dutch. Victory: The first player to accumulate 30 Population, 20 Gold, 10 Resources, and 3 Town Improvements wins. If you ever reach zero population, you automatically lose.”

name: Dark Ages Empires
description:
“Wargame for 2-8+ players. Europe Early 6th Century after the Fall of the Western Roman Empire. Victory: The player to conquer the most other nations by the end of the Game is the winner. Time Scale: Each turn is 5 years. The game starts in 500 AD and ends in 600 AD.”

Each player leads one of 20 kingdoms of early Europe. The remaining territories are neutral. If all of a player’s armies are eliminated by another player, his kingdom is conquered but the player can continue by taking control of one of the neutral kingdoms.

name: Dark Sun Skirmish
description:
A boardgame set in the AD&D Dark Sun campaign setting. Each player randomly selects a party of eight characters. To win the game a player must destroy all enemy characters. The characters come in several races, such as Halfling, Dwarf, Human, Elf, and Half Giant.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid (a chessboard would suffice.) Miniatures or counters are used to represent the characters. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

name: Desert Storm Solitaire
description:
“Solitaire card game with Desert Storm Theme.”

There are two decks in the game: The Coalition Forces Deck and The Iraqi Deck. The player controls the Coalition Forces. Points are earned for eliminating Iraqi units. Points are lost for losing Coalition units. The game ends when the Iraqi deck is exhausted.
categories: Card Game, Modern Warfare, Print & Play

name: Drop Troops
description:
“Futuristic Tactical Miniatures Ruleset. Each player controls a squad of heavily armed Drop Troopers (Space Marines.) For use with typical Space Marine pewter and plastic figs.”

The equipment provided for in the rules includes light and heavy weapons systems, grenades, pistols, hand to hand weapons, power suit systems, and armor. The rules also cover Detection, Ammo depletion, Medical Care, Repairs, Morale, Psionic Abilities, and Neohuman Races.

name: Fall of the Aztecs
description:
“Two player set piece strategic game. One player controls the Aztecs. The other player controls the Spaniards and their allies: The Totonac, Tlascalans, Texcocoans, and Cholula. Victory Conditions: The Spaniards must capture the Aztec leader Cuahtemoc. The Aztecs must capture the Spanish leader Cortez.”

The battle is fought on a hex map depicting the Aztec city of Tenochtitlan. Each Aztec unit represents 10,000 Indians. Each Spanish unit represents 100 Spaniards.

name: Wing Commander Fighters
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Takes place in the Wing Commander Universe. Abstract skirmish level Fighter combat. Each figure represents a single Fighter. Victory: You win if you destroy the opposing Wing Commander."

The game provides statistics for seven Terran Confederation Fighters and seven Kilrathi Fighters. Each player starts with two Heavy, three Medium, and three Light Fighters of their selection. One Fighter must be designated the Wing Commander. The players assign a Pilot to each one of their Fighters. There are eight named pilots for each side and each pilot has a special advantage.

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Fighting, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme

name: Tanker Skirmish
description:
A game of conflict between two armored forces. The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. A standard deck of cards is used. Red cards allow units to attack and black cards allow units to move.

Each side receives identical units: six Tanks, six Artillery, one Helicopter, and three Bases (a Command Post, Fuel Depot, and Ammo Dump.) The destruction of a Base has a negative effect on the player's other units.

The object of the game is to destroy all of the enemy Bases.

name: Russo-Turkish War
description:
"Board & card game for 2 players. Abstract simulation of the Russo-Turkish War of 1877. (Russia’s fifth war against Turkey (The Ottoman Empire) in the 19th Century.) One player is the Turks, the other is the Russians. Victory: Destroy all opposing units."

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. Each player starts with twelve units (representing 20,000 men each). Each unit can sustain three hits.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play controls how units move, attack, and defend. In addition, Recruit Cards may be played to bring back lost units.

name: Somalia 93
description:
"Card game for 2 players. Theme: The US Mogadishu Operation in Somalia on October 3, 1993. One player is the Americans. The other player is the Somalis."

Each side uses its own custom deck of cards. Each deck has three suits of cards. There are fifteen cards in each suit, each of which has a force value from 1 to 5.

The game consists of a series of card play battles where each side attempts to play cards having the highest Combat Force Total. The American force total is based on the play of Soldier, Weapon, and Tactics Cards. The Somali force total is based on the play of Combatant, Blunder, and Tactics Cards.

"If the Americans win 3 hands in a row, they are able to extract their comrades and escape. The game ends when this happens." The American player wins if the historical US casualty figure is not exceeded, otherwise the Somali player wins.

name: Squad
description:
"Card game. Simulates small unit tactics in World War II."

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. Tokens are used to represent soldiers. Two six-sided dice are also required.

"Each player starts with one squad of one of the five available nationalities. American squads start with 12 men. German, British, and Japanese squads start with 10 men. Russian platoons start with 36 men."

Differences between the nationalities are depicted in other ways, such as the number of cards drawn each turn and through National Trait Cards which have a different effect depending on which nationality plays the card. The rules also account for range, morale/rally, being pinned down, covering fire, opportunity fire, and terrain.

"Victory: There are two ways to win: Kill or rout all members of your opponents squad. Collect 3 Mission Objective Cards."
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, World War II

name: Star Control
description:
A board game based on the classic PC game.

"Alliance vs Hierarchy. Space War Strategic & Tactical. Victory: Destroy all enemy Starbases."

The game is played on two maps. There is a Galactic Starmap with three types of hexes - Void, Star (unknown worlds until explored), and Hazards (impassable spaces.) There is also a Tactical Solarmap used for fighting battles. A Planet or Starbase marker is placed in the center of the Tactical map depending on where the battle takes place.

Each side has several ship types, each rated for crew, range, speed, maneuverability, targeting effectiveness, and damage capacity.

name: Bretagne
description: Bretagne is a trivia game about this region in France.

name: Winter War
description:
A solo card game. "Simulates a battle between Soviet Union and Finland in December 1939. To be played on Finnish side."

The Finns and the Soviets each have unique custom decks of cards. The cards depict attacks, events, and weapons of the historical campaign.

Each turn the Finn player may play any standing defenses from the cards in his hand. One to six Soviet cards are then turned up (as determined by a die roll.) These cards represent the Soviet attack for the turn. The Finnish player tries to play a defensive response with a higher total Force Value than the Soviet cards. If the total Force Value of the Soviet cards is higher, the different in Force Values represents the number of casualties suffered by the Finns and is subtracted from the Finish troop count.

The player wins if there are no cards left in the Soviet deck and there are still troops remaining. If all 100 of the Finnish troops are killed, then the player loses.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, World War II

name: Invasions of the Horse People
description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Theme: Migrations/Conquests of Asiatic Nomads. Victory: The first player to accumulate 12 Loot Points is the winner."

The players all start off as Nomads. The player who wins the card contest in the Invasion Phase becomes the Khan. Only the Khan can score Loot points.

In subsequent Invasion Phases, Nomad players attempt to play cards to weaken the Khan's rule. If they are successful, the Khan will become a Nomad again and on the next turn all of the players will have a chance to become the Khan.

name: Iran-Iraq War
description:
"Card game for 2 players. Simulates the Iran- Iraq War of 1980-88. One player uses the Iraq deck. The other player uses the Iran deck."

Each turn represents a battle where the players are seeking to play cards with a higher total Force value. Some cards provide special advantages, others disadvantage your opponent. There are twelve types of cards in the game: Offensive, Defense, Air Raid, Leadership, Intelligence, Blunder, Economic Advantage, Military/Morale Advantage, Political Advantage, Military Unit, Weapon, and Fighting.

"Victory: A game lasts 16 turns. The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game wins. If a player is ever able to win 3 victory points in 3 consecutive turns, he automatically wins."

name: Mujaheddin
description:
"Card game for 2 players. Theme: Russia’s war with Afghanistan 1979-1988. The Decks: One player is the Soviets. The other player is the Afghans. Each player has his own deck. Play also requires 3 Pacification counters."

The Russian card deck consists of the following types of cards: Mission, Strategy, Units, Weapons, Politics, and Leaders. The Afghan deck includes Units, Weapons, Leaders, Advantage, Morale, and Strategy cards.

"Game End: The game ends when the Russian player has no cards left in his deck. Victory: The Soviets win if they ever get 3 Pacification counters. The Afghans win if the game ends before this."

name: Hunt the Wumpus
description:
A game of hunting the Wumpus. Each player is a hunter trying to be the first to kill the beast.

The game is played on a 7x7 array of terrain tiles. The Lair of the Wumpus is placed in the center and the hunting camps are at the four corners. The remaining spaces are randomly placed terrain tiles (clear, forest, swamp, and rocky.) The hunters start in their individual hunting camps and the Wumpus starts in the Lair.

Each player holds a hand of five cards. Cards are played to attack the Wumpus when a player is in the same square as the beast. The opposing players have the opportunity to play Evade cards to help the Wumpus evade the attack. Terrain only affects combat. Each type of Evade card is more successful in a certain type of terrain.

name: W.C. Fields Chickadee Poker
description:
W. C. Fields Chickadee Poker is a unique take on poker which includes a bit of role-play associated with the comedy of W. C. Fields prior to the actual poker on each hand.

The box has a great B&W illustration of W. C. Fields on the cover of the box, and the DOW chemical logo. There is an advertisement for DOW Oven Cleaner on the inside of the lid. The lid is attached to the box bottom and it opens like a book. Inside is a vinyl mat, thin cardboard poker chips, a non-standard deck of cards, and a rule book entitled W. C. Fields Chickadee Poker Rules; all emblazoned with images, either photographs or cartoons of W. C. Fields. All of the face cards show scenes and quote from W. C. Fields films. The components are kept in place by a thin plastic shield.

There are a lot of humorous aspects to the rules befitting the notorious character of W. C. Fields.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: L'Arche de Noé
description:
This game is from Miro's les jeux "gais loisirs" series (roughly, "happy leisure games").

Something like a updated Bingo with memory aspects, this game contains six cards containing animal pictures in various orders, a pack of 48 animal cards, rules, and oodles of purple wooden discs (to mark the animals called).

Roughly translated from the box bottom: "A new game of Bingo where animals replace numbers. Original rules make for an interesting game for both children and adults."

name: Twelve Brothers
description:
"Card game for 2-6+ players. Fantasy World Setting. King Jaspar the Just is Dying. Only one of his 12 sons can ascend to the Throne. This can only mean that 11 sons must first die."

"Each player is betting on up to 4 of the 12 Brothers to win the Crown. The 4 Brothers that a player is betting on are his Favorites."

"Victory: If one of your Favorites is the last left alive, you win. More than one player can win. It is also possible that all players lose."

name: Warring States Period
description:
"China 475 – 221 BCE. Each player is the king of one of 7 States vying for domination. Card game for 2-7 players."

There are three custom card decks used in the game - the Event Deck, Resource Deck, and Battle Deck. The Resource Deck consists of cards which can be exchanged in combos to raise taxes (Agriculture, Mines, and Cities.) The Resource Deck also contains cards for several types of Generals (Daring, Steadfast, Brilliant, Methodical, and Thoughtful.)

The Battle Deck consists of Strategy and Troop Cards. When battles are fought, the other players may choose to add cards to support the attacker or defender.

"Victory: The first player to control 15 Province Tokens wins the game."

name: Wonder Woman
description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Wonder Woman Theme."

The game is played using a custom card deck. There are ten suits in the deck: Wonder Woman, Ally, Capture, Foe, Info, Plot, Quote, Item, Action, Minion.

"The most feminist player goes first."

The players score points by playing melds of four to ten cards, each of which must come from a different suit.

"Victory: Have the most points when the deck runs out."
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Mega Tank
description:
"Solo Science Fiction Card game with two decks. You control the Mega Tank trying to wipe out the defenders more conventional forces."

The Mega Tank Deck contains cards representing the weapons, defenses, and other aspects of the Mega Tank. The Defence Force Deck contains the numerous units which are opposing the Mega Tank: infantry, bombers, tanks, guns, etc.

If the Mega Tank loses its 40 armor points, each additional point of damage causes a card to be removed from the Mega Tank Deck. If the Mega Tank Deck runs out of cards, the tank is destroyed and the player loses. If all of the Defender cards are discarded to the Casualty Pile before the Mega Tank is destroyed, the player wins.

A game apparently inspired by Ogre.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Spheres of Influence
description:
"Board & card game for 1-5+ players. Pedestrian Glass Bead Game Variant."

The game is played on a 10x10 grid with spaces large enough to contain a single game card. The deck contains over 100 cards specifying historical persons, events, things, places and ideas. Each card has one of fourteen special abilities, such as "draw 2 cards", "place an extra card this turn", or "steal one random card from opponent's hand."

Points are scored by placing cards next to cards with common characteristics. The game ends when the board is completely filled up. The player with the most points wins.

name: Knaves & Knights
description:
Abstract fantasy warfare game. The object is to destroy, capture, or control all of your opponent's pieces.

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. Each player has a set of sixteen pieces, two each of eight types: Knave, Beauty, Royalty, Knight, Sorcerer, Monster, Army, and Castle.

A six-sided die is rolled to determine movement points. These points can be split among one or more units, with each a movement point being expended for each square entered. Cards are used to make attacks. Each card may only be used by one type of unit.

name: Manifesto
description:
"Players represent ideologies in conflict in the 20th century."

The players select one Ideology to play: Democracy, Communism, Fascism, Socialism, or Imperialism. If there are more than five players, five additional Ideologies are available: Totalitarianism, Parliamentarian, Dictatorship, Monarchy, and Fundamentalism.

The game is played on a map of the world divided into twenty regions. The components also include a custom deck of cards, consisting of Conflict Cards and Influence Cards.

"Object: Control the most countries by the end of the century. Ties are resolved by bidding. Each round represents 5 years. The game starts in 1900 and ends in 2000. There are 20 game rounds."

name: Anera's Arena uitbreiding #2
description:
This limited mini-expansion adds a single character to the game: the heavily armoured knight.

Expands:

Anera's Arena

name: White Squadron
description:
The White Squadron is a set-building card game similar to the children's game "Fish" or "Go Fish."

The 52 cards in the deck depict warships of the U.S. Navy around the turn of the century. It was evidently printed in many editions because at least one copy seems to date from about 1919 based on the ships depicted, even though the original copyright date is 1896.

The ships are divided into "fleets" of four similar ships, mostly historical class sister ships ranking from "A" through "M" with each ship in the fleet numbered from "1" though "4."

For example, the "A" fleet comprises the battleships Oklahoma, Nevada, New York and Texas. The "M" fleet comprises the submarines Plunger, Porpoise, Shark and Moccasin.

Each card lists its identifying number "A-1, M-4"; the name of the ship in larger type with the sister ships in smaller type; a photograph or drawing of the ship and a three-line description.

For example, the Plunger's description reads: "PLUNGER -- Submarine torpedo boat. Holland type, operated by gasoline when in the surface and electricuty when submerged. 63 feet long. Has 3 14-inch Whitehead torpedoes for sub-sea attack."

The object of the game is to collect "fleets" of four cards with the winner being the player with the most "fleets" at the end of play.

Five cards are dealt to each player with the surplus forming a common draw pile.

The player to the dealer's left begins by asking any one player for a specific card . For example, "Do you have H-3 Massachusetts?" If the player has the card he must give it to the caller, who can then ask for another card from anyone around the table.

If the targeted player doesn't have the card, then the caller must draw one card from the draw pile and play passes to the left.

Once four cards in the same fleet are collected the player paces them down on the table face up.

If a player has no cards then he is entitled to draw two cards from the draw pile.

Once the draw pile is exhausted, play continues with the cards in hand only until all the fleets are formed.

The rules don't say, but presumably players who have no cards and can't draw from the draw pile can still continue to play and acquire cards for a fleet, although they would be vulnerable to poaching from other players.
publishers: Cincinnati Game Co., Fireside Game Co.

name: Heroes & Hordes
description:
"Solo Card game. Fantasy Theme. Summon Heroic Armies to beat back the Evil Hordes."

The game uses a custom deck containing approximately 120 cards. There are eight types of cards: Men, Elf, Dwarf, Goblin, Undead, Dragon, multi-hero, and Event. The Men, Elves, and Dwarves are the player's forces (fighting in segregated groups), and the Goblins, Undead, and Dragons make up the three Evil Hordes. Whenever a Horde eliminates a group of Heroes, the player receives a Devastation Token.

The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck at the beginning of a turn. Victory is based on the number of Devastation Tokens received: four or more is a loss, two or more is a win, and three is a tie.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Print & Play

name: Pacification of the Middle East
description:
"Solo card game. Low-Complexity Simulation of current efforts by Western Powers to stabilize the Mid-East Region in their favor. The Player takes on the Role of the US President."

The player's success is measured on four Meters which are used to determine victory. These are the Western Fear Meter, Arab Hostility Meter, Political Turmoil Meter, and Oil Control Meter.

"Victory: The Game ends at the end of 10 turns. You win a Peace Victory if at the end of the game, both the Western Fear Meter and the Arab Hostility Meter are at 5 or less. You win an Oil Victory if at the end of the game, your Oil Control Meter is 15+."

"Defeat: You lose if the Political Turmoil Meter is ever 5+ at the end of your turn: You are kicked out of Office. You lose if the Arab Hostility Meter is ever 30+ at the end of your turn: All the Arab Countries declare war against you."
categories: Card Game, Modern Warfare, Political, Print & Play

name: Indian Wars
description:
"Card game for 2 Players. Theme: American Indian Wars in the Post Civil War Years. One player is the Whites. The other player is the Indians."

The game is played using a custom card deck containing seven types of cards: Initiative, White Combatant, Indian Combatant, Firepower, Aftermath, Special, and Historical. Most of the cards are ranked with a number. Some cards can only be played by one player.

Each player starts with twenty Blood Chips. Blood Chips are won from the opposing player by playing cards having a higher total Combatant score.

"Victory: Reduce your opponent to zero Blood Chips. Note: If both players are reduced to zero at the end of a Turn, the player with the least negative total wins. A White win indicates an early end of the Indian Wars in The White Mans favor. An Indian win indicates additional Resistance and a
Continuation of the Indian Wars. (By 1870 there were more Whites in Kansas than Indians in the entire US)"
categories: American Indian Wars, Card Game, Print & Play

name: Swamp Fighters
description:
"Wet Wargame for 2 or more players. Fantasy Swamp theme. Victory: Destroy all enemy units."

Components: "Tiles are used to make the Map. Chits are used to represent Units. Each player has their own set of unit chits. Cards are used to represent Spells. Six sided dice are needed to play."

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. The terrain tiles are randomly distributed on the squares. There are five races of creatures which live in the swamp: Lizard Men, Crab Men, Bullywugs, Snake Men, and Turtle Men. The players choose to play one of these races, controlling 20 or 21 creatures in a battle to the death.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: Drunken Coachman
description: "... the Amusing Game played in Naval Messes." This is a small box card game where the goal is to move the Coachman figure between players using the cards dealt to you at the beginning of the game (they move the card a certain number of players left or right". If a stop if played you lose a chit from your stock (you star with twelve) to the centre. A "fares please" card gets you one stock counter from each player. The person who has the Coachman in Front of them at the end wins the chits from the centre. You play to a set total score or until all but one player is eliminated. The original game makes you play your cards without looking at them but a suggested variant of playing from your hand make it more interesting. This is one of a number of light English Card Games created during the 1930's. There is no publisher, author or date on the game.

name: Gettysburg: The Battlefield Game
description:
Gettysburg: The Battlefield Game is a very popular game that presents an unusual look at this greatest Civil War battle, taking 2 to 6 players on a competitive "tour" of the famous battlefield. Union and Confederate players play to win, using knowledge and luck, experiencing incidents and events from the climactic three-day battle in July 1863.

The game includes a 4-part game board, a d6, six stand up figures (3 union, 3 confederate) a rule sheet, and a battle book. The battle book contains trivia questions and historic anecdotes that affect the outcome of the game.

name: Gobsmacked!
description:
Place 3 in a row of the same color or shape and your opponent scores a point in this maniacal memory game. It's enough to make your mind spin as you try to remember the pattern on the board before it's spun around and another patterned plug is added into play.

Was black on the right and whit on the left? and square below and circle above? Avoid putting 3 same pattern pieces in a row to win the game.

Contents:
1 vertical wooden board, 1 wood stand, 22 playing pieces, 2 Gobsmackers, instructions.

name: Ronin: War
description:
Ronin is a tactical and customizable miniatures game of gigantic mechanized battle. Ronin:War introduces tanks, flying machines, and other units along with a new set of added rules to bring large-scale battle to the world of Ronin. Command your units to eliminate enemy forces, while marching your superior Ronin mechs across the battlefield for an epic showdown.

Expands:

Ronin: Duels
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Pingo Tour
description:
2 to 4 children slip into the role of penguins in this dice game. The move from ice hole to ice hole, hunting fish. (So far, nothing new.) However, the game is filled with small tasks (throwing fish into the air & seeing which side they land on, for example) in order to obtain the fish. The game also has suggestions on how it can be used with a larger group such as a kindergarten class.

Contents:
• 1 wooden game board (370 x 370 x 10 mm)
• 1 dice with colours / symbols
• 4 penguin figures
• 40 fish
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

name: Monopoly: Gosforth
description: This version of Monopoly is based upon the English area of Gosforth of Newcastle upon Tyne. The blue properties are now sandwich shops, the red properties are clothing shores, and the orange ones are now hairdressers with the locations of Go, Jail, Waterworks, and the Electric Company remaining the same.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Generals' Order
description:
Generals Order is a Chinese-language CCG published in Singapore to expose Singapore players to the Chinese language and culture.

From the publisher website :

Generals Order is a game that simulates ancient battlefield scenario that combines Wisdom (devising strategies), Courage (deploying generals) and Calculation (resource management).

In this battle of wits and courage, you are the commanding general who leads the army in their conquest of the world. How to ensure victory, change the course of events or turn defeat into victory, is all decided by your each and every action.

CARD TYPES
There are 4 types of card-types in the Generals Order SCG

General (Character) Card
Equipment Card
Event Card
Special Card

General cards play an important role in the attacking of opponent’s castle as well as defending your own castle from attack. All General cards have its own unique special ability to assist the players in their conquest.

Equipment cards can enhance the strength of the General Cards permanently.

Event cards effect are temporary but the effect is far superior to Equipment cards.

Special cards are the only type of cards that can be used during opponent’s turn. They are mainly used to counter opponent’s attack or event.

Home Page: http://www.generals-order.com/

name: Alice
description: This game consists of 44 cards. There are 8 sets of 5 cards each, 2 white rabbit cards, and 2 Cheshire Cat cards. The artwork on these cards is based on the Disney movie. This game has a very "Go Fish" feel to it where players are trying to assemble sets by asking each other for cards. However, players can refuse to give up cards by playing white rabbit cards. Additionally, if a player has asked for a card from a player who does not have it, he can play a Cheshire Cat card for a second chance. The game is played in several rounds until one player reaches 50 points.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Baccardo
description:
Baccardo is an old horse racing card game. It consists of 50 cards and is playable by exactly 4 players. During a game, 1 player is the "bookie" and the others are all "punters."

46 of the cards are horse cards, and the other 4 are one each of "policeman", "welsher", "tipster" and "the odds."

name: Bread & Honey
description: This game is played with a pack of 53 cards and is based on the nursery rhyme "Sing a Song of Sixpence." The colorful cards feature the different characters from the rhyme. This is a war-like game where cards are dealt face down to players and they turn cards up one at a time, battling to steal each others cards until finally one player holds all. Special cards like clowns, queens, kings, and maids dictate how many cards must be turned up.

name: British Birds
description: The deck consists of 44 cards. There are 8 sets of 5 bird cards, and 4 owl cards. Each of the 8 sets have a letter on them, then each of the birds within the set are numbered 1 through 5. The object of the game is to collect as many sets of 5 with the same letter on them as you can. The game proceeds with players asking for cards from each other and assembling sets. If you have a card but don't want to give it up, you may play an owl card. As soon as you have a set of 5, lay it down in front of you. When all sets have been assembled the game is over.

name: K'uhul
description:
A quick playing game of wits for 2 players.

The K'uhul is a sacred ring of standing stone statues, once erected to appease the bloodthirsty god, Coatlicue. Although many mysteries surround K'uhul, it has remained fairly harmless over the past 1000 years.

Now two rival shamans have arrived to worship at the sacred site and discover that they are in violent disagreement over the origins and purpose of K'uhul. The only thing they agree on is that K'uhul is a gate to untold power.

As their increasingly heated arguments begin to disrupt the local village--the village Head Man decides to end the bickering by holding a contest: the first shaman to be able to successfully activate the power of K'uhul will win the respect and riches of the village, while the loser will be sacrificed to appease Coatlicue--who is no doubt annoyed by the constant bickering.

The contest is held on a 3x3 grid within the ring of sacred statues. The ring of statues is formed by making piles of "gate chips" which surround 9 single chips which form the gate itself. The gate chips come in two styles, Runes and Stars, and the 3x3 pattern they form must be manipulated to match that of one of the special "gate cards". By arranging the chips to match the pattern of a gate card, a shaman can "unlock" the gate.

Gameplay is further complicated by the presence of several types of "special" chips as well as "spell" cards that are activated when a gate card is "unlocked".

The first player to successfully "unlock" two of the face-up gate cards PLUS a final gate card from their own hand, will be declared the winner. The loser is then sacrificed during the ensuing celebration to the merriment of all.

name: Séð og heyrt skemmtispilið
description: A trivia game based solely on news and articles from the glamor magazine Séð & heyrt (an Icelandic version of the Danish magazine Se & Hør). There are 2100 questions about the famous, various happenings and glamor stories. Play can be for 2-6 people or for teams with 1-6 players.

name: Oktaeder
description:
In Oktaeder ("Octahedron") players take turns to stack one of their marbles into the playing area, building up an octahedron as the game progresses. The object is to form lines of four marbles of the player's color.

Oktaeder is similar to Kessler's game Giseh! but with an octahedral playing area instead of a pyramid. A transparent stand is provided with the game to hold the base of the octahedron during gameplay.

name: Monopoly: Somerset Edition
description: This version of Monopoly is based upon the English area of Somerset. Proposed landmark locations include St. Mary Magdalene Church and Wells Cathedral.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Parker Brothers, Winning Moves UK Ltd.

name: The New World Game of American History
description:
"The New World: A game of American history from discovery to James K. Polk."

This antique card game consisted of a set of forty cards in a slipcase. Twenty of the cards depict famous people in American history with clues to their identity. The other twenty cards contain questions and answers about the original colonies and the first eleven presidents. The object of the game is to match corresponding cards from the two sets.

The game also includes an advertising card listing other games available from Josiah Adams.

name: Lizard Lunch!
description: Lizard's Lunch! is a children's action game. Each player takes a hand-held chameleon with a long sticky tongue. The players try to flick the tongue to grab shiny, plastic flies off of the table or ground. Whoever grabs the most wins. The game includes two chameleons and sixteen flies.

name: Word Ladder
description: The game originally known as Doublet or Word-links. A player is given a start word and an end word. In order to win the game, the player must change the start word into the end word by creating a new word at each step. To do this a player must either change a letter, add a letter, remove a letter, or rearrange the letters in different order like an anagram.

name: Dumbo Card Game
description: A rummy variation card game based on the 1941 Disney movie. The deck comes with 45 cards. There are 4 suits with cards numbered 1 through 11, and 1 Dumbo joker card. The game is for 2 to 4 players, but 4 players requires a second deck. First player to get to 50 points wins.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Whipcash
description:
Don't be a victim. Protect yourself from crooked doctors, crooked lawyers and crooked insurance companies that will rip you off. Learn the dirty rotten tricks of psychological manipulation designed to get your money and can end up destroying your life.

You and your friends will have the time of your life trying to bankrupt each of the three shady pros...
then you'll have even more fun trying to bankrupt each other!

From the official website: www.whipcash.com

name: Pendulum
description:
Pendulum is a simple action game for 2 players, each with 7 wooden cylindrical playing pieces (1.25 inches tall). These pieces are placed upright on the wooden playing board (15 x 7 inches), at the center of which there is a pendulum made of a one inch diameter wooden ball affixed to a 10 inch long string. Players take turns pulling back the ball and letting go it, allowing it to free-swing in any direction around the board. A player wins the round by knocking over the opponent's 7 pieces before all of one's own pieces are knocked over by the pendulum.

Variants described in the instruction booklet include St. Louie ("The Pendulum Dice Game"), Tower Tumble (noncompetitive), and Bowling.

Pendulum has a small 16 page instruction booklet which includes 14 black and white photos, most of young children playing the game. There is one picture (from about 1900) of an outdoor game of 'quilles', described as "an early pendulum game developed in France in the 14th century."

According to the booklet, Pendulum's "composition is of a Folk Toy Style." Its board design is "taken from a 12th century A.D. Jain Temple at Kathiawar built to honor Patala, a land devoted to games."

The game book is attributed to Anne Rivers and Carl Chase. The game and package design are attributed to Carl Chase. Pendulum was distributed in the mid-1980's by Pinocchio's, located in Kalamazoo, Michigan.

name: Speed Grammar
description:
Publisher's description: "Kids love Speed Grammar's three fun bingo-style games that reinforce nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, pronouns, and prepositions."

"Spin the shaker and race to find the correctly color-coded sentence. 'I found a sentence with a red noun, blue verb, orange adjective, and green preposition.' Speed Grammar quickly builds grammar and reading skills as students make matches."

"Colorful cards, unique game shakers, and fast-paced game play offer a hands-on alternative to traditional grammar worksheets. Perfect for learning centers. Includes 3 game shakers, 12 double-sided cards, and 50 game markers. For 2 to 4 players. Grades 3 and up."

name: Roulette Russa
description:
A giant roulette wheel with 28 holes, each hole has a number 1 to 4. Players have 5 marbles and roll them on the roulette wheel trying to make combinations.
You can score point with a combination of three of your marbles, three of the generic marbles, make a complete section (you can make a section of 7 marbles using the marble of other player), and more....
Whoever scores 50 points or more wins the game.

name: American Indian Map Game
description:
The American Indian Map Game is played by collecting cards by correctly identifying Indian tribes, culture areas, language groups, or subsistence patterns, relating to the game board on which there are represented the geographic regions of 40 tribes and 10 culture areas of the U.S., Canada, and northern Mexico.

The American Indian Map Game is one in the series of Educational Materials Associates' educational Learningames. The rules for this game are a generic set of rules that can be used for other Learningames.

name: Balance: So spielt das Leben
description: Die Autostadt GmbH and Volkswagen AG have collaborated with Ravensburger in this game of Balance. It is actually four games contained in one which all use a balance tip with a tabletop on it that will shift its position with the stacking of chips. It can be played as a basic childrens dexterity game and as a party game with cards that present social dilemmas that need to be answered with a "Yes" or "No". This game appears to have mainly been distributed by the company Die Autostadt GmbH in Germany.

name: Jester's Dream
description:
Simple card games, Ages 7 and up, where players are jesters on a quest to become knights for the love of their princess.
It's a DTP card game, available for print & play through Wargamedownloads, Arima and Wargaming Online

name: Glop
description:
Contents: four series of eleven cards, numbered from 1 to 11, 1 board and 3 pawns for keeping track of the scores and of the strongest colour.

One must compare his hand with the values of those set upon the table. He choose any set of cards face-up which values add to the total of the one he chooses to play,and collect all those cards. If the captured set is of maximum size, it is called a “glop”, and this is rewarded with more scoring points. The first to raise 30 points wins.

name: Gargoyles the Movie Game
description:
Bonus game included with the VHS and Laser Disc release of Gargoyles the Movie: The Heroes Awaken (a compilation of the first five episodes).

Components included: game board, "Building" cards, Demona "Wild" cards, Elisa "Badge" cards, spinner (1, 2, 3), and four player tokens (Goliath, Brooklyn, Lexington, Broadway).

Players were instructed to keep the video running after they finished watching the movie. The video would occasionally flash, and the player whose turn it was would have to follow the orders of the character (Xanatos, Elisa, or Demona) that appeared on screen.
publishers: Buena Vista Home Video (Buena Vista Software)

name: Super Heat Skate Card Game
description:
For two to six people, all ages. Experience the thrill of competitive skater action any time, anywhere! Compete for the most points to win. Easy to learn. Great to trade and collect.

Each 104 card deck has six character cards and 12 manoeuvre cards for each player, plus bonus point and penalty cards.

name: Pyramid Pyramid
description:
The Pharaoh is getting old and he does not have a successor. One day he gathers his closest advisers and issues a challenge: "Build me a pyramid. Whoever contributes the most shall be the next Pharaoh!". Who will rise the challenge and become the new ruler of the land?

Players roll dice and draw event cards to maneuver their pyramid-building blocks around the board and into the pyramid at the center. Points are scored for each block added to the pyramid. Bonus points are given for blocks that end up on the outside of the pyramid. Players need to manage their supply of building blocks carefully since the board is cleared after each level of the pyramid is completed and buying back the blocks costs points. After the pyramid is completed whoever has the most points wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Rubik's Line Up
description: "Take a turn and make a line up: a fun game for all ages that is not as simple as it looks." Twelve cubes with each face a different colour populate a 6x6 board. Players take turns to roll a cube from one square to another with the object of completing a line of three cubes with the same colour uppermost.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Pattern Building, Square Grid
